results.description:
WHY DO THEY WEAR BROWN PAPER BAGS?
Come learn about LGBTQ asylum seekers in our community – where they came from, why they are here, and the hidden facts that news anchors won’t tell you.

The “Bad Old Days” Aren’t Over for Everyone. Fifty years ago, almost all LGBTQ people were afraid for our lives and our jobs. Progress! Yet, in many places today, persecuted LGBTQ people are still in hiding for their lives. Homophobic attitudes and laws—including the “Kill the Gays” bill in Uganda—are a result of U.S. evangelists’ intentional incitement of fear and hate. Come hear personal stories from the lives of our brothers and sisters who are still being persecuted, just for being who they are.

Learn how you can make a difference.

JOIN US for a chance to MEET & HEAR the personal stories of ASYLUM SEEKERS!
A fundraiser and “friendraiser” for the LGBT Asylum Support Task Force

Sunday, January 10th, 7:30-10:00 pm

Hosted by the Cambridge Men's Group ... ALL ARE WELCOME!

BRING your heart, your friends, your interest in learning, and your checkbook!

Invite your Facebook friends, too: http://on.fb.me/1NwK3qC

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

This is the first Meetup for the Boston Area Greenhouse User Community. We plan to have some light food and drink and will talk about things we've learned about the system and ask what others have learned as well. This should be collaborative and informative for all. There are all sorts of different ways that people use this product and we thought it was worth coming together to discuss best practices and the realities of running Greenhouse out-of-the-box.

Itinerary:

5:30-6/6:15 - Food, Drinks, hobnobbing
6:15-7:30 - Greenhouse Boston User Group Kickoff

We'll talk about the goals of the group, setup a pass-the-mic atmosphere, and dig into some content, including:

- Why Greenhouse isn't Taleo/iCims/Jobvite/etc
- The Who Book and why it helps
- Product Features few talk about, integrations (Linkedin, Docusign)
- Hacks, Tricks, Tweaks that can help GH hum along

** Remember to sign up with first and last name due to building security at 101 Arch.

An MBA changes you, professionally and personally: Meet us in Boston


EXCLUSIVE FREE ENTRY: The QS World MBA Tour will be making a stop at the Colonnade Hotel in Boston on January 26th, from 4 - 9 pm.  Our event is your opportunity to meet face-to-face with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools. Attendees will be eligible to apply for exclusive MBA scholarships worth $1.7M and attend educational panels and seminars. Get valuable advice on the MBA essay, application and interview process, and have all your MBA questions answered in one place! Attending Business Schools Include: Boston University, Boston College, UMass-Amherst, George Washington Univ., Northeastern Univ., Tufts Univ. - Fletcher, Univ. of Arizona - Eller, Vanderbilt Univ., Univ. of Miami, Suffolk Univ., Nova Southeastern Univ. London School of Economics and Political Science and more. Entry is free for BNT members, but places are limited, so be sure to Register Now for FREE. When you check in for our Boston event, please present a copy of this offer to obtain free entry.


Microsoft New England was founded with the recognition that the greater Boston area is home to the world’s leading universities, cutting edge technology and the vibrant investment and emerging growth company community, and our campus plays a leading role in building our presence among these communities. Follow @MSNewEngland and join them on facebook. www.microsoftcambridge.com


Mobinett Interactive specializes in strategy, design and development for mobile/web apps and backend software. Please contact us if you need any advice or help! Check out our "Top 10 Questions to Ask In Hiring a Mobile App Developer" and other helpful resources on the Mobinett Blog. Visit www.Mobinett.com, contact us here, or call <a>[masked]</a>. Follow @mobinett.

Products & Presenters:

1. Beacons In Space - Power Modern Context (Ben Smith) Tech: ibeacon. www.BeaconsInSpace.com

2. Censio / @GetCensio - Mobile app and platform for auto insurers makes driving safer & more affordable. (Matt McClure / @MatthewLMcclure) Tech: iOS, Android, Python, AWS, Cassandra, PostGIS, Ansible. www.cens.io

4. The Hawaii Project / @TheHawaiiProj - Personalized book discovery engine powered by the web's leading tastemakers (Mark Watkins / @viking2917) Tech: AngularJS, PHP, MySql, EC2. www.thehawaiiproject.com


5. My onCampus Chef / @myOnCampusChef - Your Campus is full of amazing chefs! Homefood is Happiness! (Gianmarco Di Pino / @GianmarcoDiPino) www.myOnCampusChef.com

6. LiveRes / @LiveResUPDATES - Connecting Employers with qualified Job-Seekers INSTANTLY! (Doug Cochrane) www.Live-Resume.com

7. Jowl / @Jowlco - Simplified community software for brands. (Quinn Cully / @Shoger41) Tech: PHP. www.Jowl.co

Agenda:


6:00 to 7:00 - Networking with dinner and beverages in "Commons" (11th floor and walk through the glass doors and down the stairs)

7:00 to 7:10 - Announcements

7:10 to 8:30 - Presentations, Q&A

8:30 to 9:00 - More Networking

Directions & Parking:


Microsoft's building has a parking garage in the basement, which is $10 after 4 PM. MIT offers FREE parking in any non-gated lot on campus after 5 PM. MIT's Hayward St Lot is the closest (park in the white spaces, not the yellow). Memorial Drive has free parking, but the spaces in front of NERD have a 1 hour limit. Other area streets have metered parking.

Public Transportation: Microsoft NERD is a 5 minute walk from the Kendall Square MBTA station on the Red Line.

Get directions & more info here.

Upon arrival, you must show a government issued, photo ID to Security and sign the attendee roster. Take an elevator to the 11th floor and walk through the glass doors. At our check-in desk, type in your first or last name, to print your name tag.

We are excited to announce our first Drinks On Tap event for 2016!!

Drinks On Tap is a social meetup for Boston area mobile developers (iPhone, Android and more). Come meet for a drink and catch up on all the new mobile developments at our next Drinks On Tap event - Monday, January 11th at Ned Devine's in Faneuil Hall from 6PM-9PM. 

Our sponsor, who will also be demoing, for the evening will be:

Lookout is a cybersecurity company focused on mobile. Protecting individuals and enterprises alike, Lookout fights cybercriminals by predicting and stopping mobile attacks before they do harm. 

Here are demos for the evening: 

Ovuline is a Boston-based health-technology company that is committed to making healthcare an everyday lifestyle for women.  Its first products to market, Ovia Fertility and Ovia Pregnancy, give women personalized information that helps them get pregnant and have healthy pregnancies.  

Supermassive is an addicting arcade game with a simple goal: Destroy enemy shapes, gain their mass, and grow big enough to become a black hole.

Based on its founders’ true love story, Jess, Meet Ken is a dating app for women to recommend guys who may not be right for them but could be GREAT for someone else.  All men must be nominated by a woman who knows him best, writing why he’s so great.  When a man and woman match they may chat or the woman may chat with the lady who nominated the guy, to learn a bit more about him before an introduction is made.

Looking forward to a great event!  


Be sure to spread the word: @DrinksOnTap and #DrinksOnTap! 


Note: This event is 21+ only.

results.description:
Dr. Andrew West:
Billions and Billions of Planets and the Red Dwarfs that (Mostly) Host Them

Join us on January 11th at 7:00pm at the Burren, for Science by the Pint.

Andrew West is an Associate Professor of Astronomy at Boston University and an expert on the smallest stars in the galaxy (called red dwarfs). His class “Alien Worlds” is focused on the planets around other stars (called exoplanets), and has been named one of the Top Ten “Craziest” college classes in the country by the Huffington Post. It was converted into a Massive Open Online Class (MOOC; more than 12,000 students have taken it) on the EdX platform, and is the subject of a Reddit AMA.

For Science by the Pint, Professor West and the members of his research and teaching teams will talk about the amazing discoveries in the field of exoplanets and how the smallest stars will certainly play a role in finding our nearest habitable (and/or inhabited) planet. Professor West will discuss that, for the first time in human history, we know that planets are common around other stars and that most of the stars in our Galaxy (and others) are not like our Sun, but instead cooler, smaller, and fainter. He will talk about what we know about exoplanets and what his research group is doing to study and help characterize the red dwarfs around which most exoplanets orbit.


Science by the Pint is sponsored by an organization of Harvard graduate students called Science in the News.  In between their sleepless hours of hard work at Harvard Med School, they bring cutting edge scientific research to the public in a fun and informal format. 


The Burren is located on Elm Street right in the heart of Davis Square, just a short walk from the Red Line stop.  If you prefer to drive, there are metered spots on the street and in nearby municipal lots (see link below).  Meters are active until 8:00 PM, and metered spots are free thereafter. Municipal lot meters are good for three hours, and street spots are good for two.

Links:

Discovering Alien Worlds


SITN Facebook Page

SITN: Science by the Pint

The Burren

Davis Square Parking

Happy chatting and best wishes on your endeavors!  

As always, I welcome any questions you may have regarding our group or your business ventures!

Community Note: Meetings Planned to Discuss Somerville Zoning Overhaul 


The Mayor’s Office of Strategic Planning and Community Development (OSPCD) announced today a series of meetings marking the next step in the Somerville Zoning Overhaul process. The meetings, which will cover a wide variety of topic areas, will be held from November 2015
through March 2016, and will discuss the ideas within the City’s new proposed zoning ordinance, respond to comments provided in the public review process, and propose changes to the ordinance based upon this feedback. The Jan 11th meeting will include the following topics, among others: 


- Inclusionary zoning
- linkage
- development bonuses

results.description:
Exquisite corpse it's not only for the surrealists (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exquisite_corpse)

Last time we tried a game I've been developing, exquisite corpse for programmers. We're going to run another round of it, this time with lessons learned.

What is exquisite corpse for programmers? It's simply this:

0) Write a failing test

1) Pass your computer on

2) Get a computer with a failing test

3) Fix the test (without modifying the test case)

4) Goto 0

We're going to work in javascript with NodeJS and mocha. If you can please bring a computer with all that installed and able to run a test case. Also as always with group coding please have a vanilla text editor available (sublime, text edit...) no VIM or emacs please.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
{Pick up new insights about your own relationships, while supporting and getting to know a fellow member of the MetroWest personal growth community}


Our Guest This Evening

Wendy Williams, R.N., M.Ed., is a PGN member from Framingham who is passionate about helping married people break out of old ruts and connect again with their significant others.

As a marriage mentor, she helps couples create soul-satisfying (re)connections with simple, reliable, practical methods. She also co-hosts the weekly Mighty Married Moms podcast, where she regularly interviews guests on topics related to health, relationships, and family life. 

Wendy is coming to this evening's Heartbeat Salon not only to share some of what she's learned and observed about long-term relationships, but also -- and perhaps more importantly -- to share her story, and ask for our collective wisdom and guidance as she seeks to have the greatest possible impact in her work. 

Some of the key questions she's coming with include:

• How do different people relate to the things I have to say about marriage and relationships? Is it relevant to people who have never been married, or are no longer married, or are in same-sex relationships? 

• What parts of what I offer are most needed, and most helpful? Is it information I have to share? The coaching process? A particular philosophy or mindset? Mentoring and encouragement?

• How can I describe what I do in a way that is compelling to the people who are most likely to benefit from it?


The evening will be a facilitated group dialogue, where Wendy will be invited to share her work, her excitement, and her challenges, and then field questions and comments from the group. 


What's in it for You

By attending this event you will have the opportunity to:


• Get to know a fellow member of the MetroWest Personal Growth Community more deeply

• Share your own wisdom and life experiences with someone who is actively seeking help and support

• Learn something about long-term relationships that will be relevant to you --whether you're currently in one or not.


• Be inspired by a leader who is courageously navigating her life's journey into new and exciting territory 

How to Prepare

Taking some time to learn a little about Wendy and her work before the meeting is optional, but it will make your feedback even more valuable. Here are some places to look, if you have the time:


• Wendy's website, http://www.connectagain.org/ introduces you to her services, with a bunch of practical relationship tips included in her blog.


• Wendy is one of three co-hosts of the Mighty Married Moms podcast. You can hear her commentary at http://mightymarriedmoms.com/ 

• This 35-minute podcast with John Gray (of Mars/Venus fame) is one Wendy cited as influential to her approach and philosophy.

If you don't have time to prepare, don't worry. You will be able to contribute to the conversation just by showing up and being you. 

Links

Most Important:   
  * Other, Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 
  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon?  
  *  Where are Heartbeat Salons  
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Hosts: 
  * How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics to Offer at a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Presenters: 
  * How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Your Suggestions: 
  * Give Us Your Ideas (topics, locations, etc) . 

9/03/15

results.description:
Eric Weiner discusses The Geography of Genius: A Search for the World's Most Creative Places from Ancient Athens to Silicon Valley

This event is free and includes a book signing; no tickets are required.

Monday, January 11th, 7pm

Harvard Book Store - 1256 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store welcomes ERIC WEINER, bestselling author of The Geography of Bliss, for a discussion of his latest work, The Geography of Genius: A Search for the World's Most Creative Places from Ancient Athens to Silicon Valley. 

Travel the world with Eric Weiner as he journeys from Athens to Silicon Valley—and throughout history, too—to show how creative genius flourishes in specific places at specific times.

In The Geography of Genius, acclaimed travel writer Weiner sets out to examine the connection between our surroundings and our most innovative ideas. He explores the history of places, like Vienna of 1900, Renaissance Florence, ancient Athens, Song Dynasty Hangzhou, and Silicon Valley, to show how certain urban settings are conducive to ingenuity. And, with his trademark insightful humor, he walks the same paths as the geniuses who flourished in these settings to see if the spirit of what inspired figures like Socrates, Michelangelo, and Leonardo remains. In these places, Weiner asks, “What was in the air, and can we bottle it?”

This link can be traced back through history: Darwin’s theory of evolution gelled while he was riding in a carriage. Freud did his best thinking at this favorite coffee house. Beethoven, like many geniuses, preferred long walks in the woods.

Sharp and provocative, The Geography of Genius redefines the argument about how genius came to be. His reevaluation of the importance of culture in nurturing creativity is an informed romp through history that will surely jumpstart a national conversation.Praise

“An intellectual odyssey, a traveler’s diary, and a comic novel all rolled into one. Smart, original, and utterly delightful.” —Daniel Gilbert, Harvard professor and bestselling author of Stumbling on Happiness

“A charming mix of history and wisdom cloaked as a rollicking travelogue.” —Walter Isaacson, bestselling author of Steve Jobs

::  :: ::

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked] 

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked] 

Accessibility Inquiries: [masked]
results.name: Geography of Genius?

results.description:
Notice the change of day for this particular event: Monday.  We are going to try to do some of the Tuesdays at Adam's house (with a Monday event at my house this same week).  Hopefully we get more gaming options and more people can participate in at least one of the events.

===========


Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.
results.name: Board Games in Sudbury

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

Explore the Science of Happiness-- and discover tools to increase your happiness and well-being, as well as that of clients and organizations, through positive pathways. Learn why this red hot, leading-edge field is such a powerful approach and how it helps individuals and organizations to flourish in the faster-moving energy of today's world. Learn about the Certificate in Applied Positive Psychology (CAPP) that has become so popular.

Have you ever wanted new, proven tools to increase happiness and well-being in your clients, family and yourself?  Discover what the Science of Happiness and Human Flourishing offers.

We will:

+ Discuss Dr. Martin Seligman’s (Founder of Positive Psychology) Flourishing Model and physical well-being

+ Consider how Positive Psychology changes the fundamental questions, the game, and the results

+ Explore the Back-by-popular-demand- Certificate in Positive Psychology--Starting in Boston on March 5.


About the Leader: Christine Duvivier

Christine Duvivier, a Master of Positive Psychology, studied and worked with Dr. Martin Seligman and other luminaries in the field, at UPenn. She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands worldwide, including Fortune 50 and other executives, individuals, families, and communities. She teaches and coaches other professionals, including physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors.

Christine has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17. She re-ignited and re-engaged leaders and employees worldwide in a 55,000-person firm that resulted in a 40% increase in customer loyalty. While at UPenn, she experienced the power and speed of positive approaches when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience.  Most importantly for her, she’s seen her family happiness increase.  www.christineduvivier.com

Note: this will be a video chat -- you'll get the information emailed to you after you register.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Tuesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

Please join us and our awesome presenters at Boston's Liquid Art House on January 12th at 5:30 pm.  Refreshments will be provided.


Topic:  Continuous Data Management for Hadoop and Spark – On-Premise or in the Cloud. 

KEYNOTE SPEAKER: 

James Campigli, Chief Product Officer and Co-Founder Wandisco

Jim has over 25 years of software industry experience at both early-stage and public companies. In his current role he is responsible for overseeing WANdisco's product strategy. In his previous role as a founder and chief technology officer (CTO) of Librados, an application integration software provider, Jim was responsible for overall product strategy and product messaging.  He was also a member of the management team that led the company’s acquisition by NetManage, Inc. Following its acquisition, Jim joined NetManage as CTO for the Librados products group. 

Prior to Librados, he was the vice president of product management for Insevo, a middleware company specializing in enterprise application integration. Jim also held senior product management, product marketing and consulting management positions at BEA Systems and SAP AG.  

- Big SQL - Making all of your big data SQL accessible using an optimal execution strategy.  Presenters:
Rick Tarro, Jeffrey Carlson - IBM Analytics

Big Data makes it possible to inexpensively store and process petabytes of structured, unstructured and semi-structured data generated at incredible speeds. However, the ultimate benefits of big data are lost if fresh, fast-moving data is not analyzed as it happens. Fast data is about data in motion—immediate response and action. 

The collection process for data in motion is essentially the same as data at rest, but the key difference is the analysis occurs in real time as data is generated and captured. However, this analysis has to include the historical context provided by data at rest in order to be meaningful. This requires an enterprise-ready architecture that efficiently handles both data at rest and data in motion with the following components: 

- An enterprise grade Big Data platform to support real-time analytics applications without downtime or data loss 
- A flexible and agile cloud environment for cost-effective burst-out processing 
- A data migration/replication engine that exceeds the most demanding application SLAs. 

This meet up will provide an overview of the “best in class” architecture required to harness the benefits of Big Data with “Continuous Data Management for Hadoop and Spark” 

 Big SQL provides ANSI SQL access to data across any system from Hadoop, via JDBC or ODBC - seamlessly whether that data exists in Hadoop or a relational data base. This means that developers familiar with the SQL programming language can access data in Hadoop without having to learn new languages or skills. Big SQL sets a new bar: performance. Benchmark tests indicate that Big SQL executes queries 20 times faster, on average, over Apache Hive 12 with performance improvements ranging up to 70 times faster. It can query and combine data from many data sources, including (but not limited to) DB2 for Linux, Teradata, Oracle, UNIX and Windows database software, IBM PureData System for Analytics. 

With Big SQL, all of your big data is SQL accessible. It presents a structured view of your existing data, using an optimal execution strategy, given your available resources. 


Parking Information:
Revere Hotel at 200 Stuart Street - $10 for 3 hours
The outdoor Laz parking lot across the street, behind Smith & Wollensky - $7 ($5 off)
results.name: Continuous Data Management for Hadoop and Spark – On-Premise or in the Cloud

Join writer, filmmaker of "Simply Raw: Reversing Diabetes in 30 Days," Eating Behavior and Psychology researcher, Tree of Life Teacher (trained by Dr. Gabriel Cousens), and author of the new book, "Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey," Michael Bedar, for a special presentation featuring themes, tips, and practices from his newly released book, and more!

Enjoy delicious healthy food and benefit from Michael Bedar’s talk and new book, Sweet Healing:

• Inspire and teach yourself to achieve workable health goals and live in sustained vital wellness.

• Use this breathtaking new book to go on a psychological journey that instills a lasting affinity for health and well-being.

• Pick up this book as a great read or a wonderful gift that keeps on giving to friends and family this Winter!

• Bring your questions, as Michael, the author, will discuss goals, emotions, and methods of gaining wellness all portrayed in the novel he wrote on the shift from dis-ease to thriving.

Find Out Why Well-Known Leaders, and Readers Alike, are Glowing about Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey:

"The new book by Michael Bedar, Sweet Healing, touches the heart and opens the mind's eye."

– Dr. Brian Clement, Director of Hippocrates Health Center


“Sweet Healing rocks! It’s a heck of an adventure for novel lovers; it’s a tale that will touch anyone who has been effected by the epidemic of diabetes and chronic disease...a gripping read of fiction that will leave you inspired, motivated, and hungry for a healthier lifestyle. Devour this book and share it with your friends now!”


– Cathy Silvers, actor from the TV sitcom, Happy Days, author of Happy Days, Healthy Living, producer of The Healthy Living Show


“Michael Bedar's wonderful new book, 'Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey,' offers a proven and essential alternative narrative to help you observe and identify what blocks you in life, and incorporate lifestyle practices you can use for whole-person health.”

- From the Foreword by Gabriel Cousens, MD, MD(H) author of Rainbow Green Live-Food Cuisine, Conscious Eating, and There Is a Cure for Diabetes


“Sweet Healing is filled with Michael’s dedication, caring, and generous personality, infused with serving and raising awareness for the world around him as if it were his own family. In this book you’ll find a great story to help avail yourself to wisdom and knowledge about eating and living a healthier lifestyle. A story written like this comes from someone walking his talk. Sweet Healing is inspiring to those suffering with preventable and reversible illnesses, so they may create new habits and ways of living that reinforce a loving, healthy sense of self.”

– Debbie Merrill, US Figure Skating Silver-Medalist, author of Raw Truth to the Fountain of Youth, host of the Debbie Merrill Show


“For people searching, this book is a parable about waking up and getting your spark back par excellence! I heartily and excitedly recommend Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey as a boon to those who want to find out what’s possible in the realm of their well-being. Read it on a plane, in bed, in a book club, or on your train commute–just READ it!”

– Nomi Shannon, Author of What Do Raw Fooders Eat 1 & 2, The Raw Gourmet, and Raw Food Celebrations

“If you or you family are faced with the challenge of type 2 diabetes, I recommend that you read Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey now. It is an indispensable parable. It will take you on a possible journey to better health and a life empowered by positive choices, informed by proven research and presented as an entertaining read." – Mike Adams, the Health Ranger, editor of NaturalNews.com


"Sweet Healing - A Whole Health Journey is a 'Way of the Peaceful Warrior' and 'Celestine Prophecy'-type adventure for today's epidemic times."

- Annie Padden Jubb, author of Secrets of an Alkaline Body, owner of LifeFood Restaurant Chain LA

“If you know someone who’s faced with type 2 diabetes or a degenerative metabolic health crisis, I highly recommend this inspirational novel! In Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey, the characters demonstrate how each small step in the process of healing builds upon itself. This book inspires readers to take a proactive approach to their healing and offers innovative tips for health, happiness, and longevity.”

– Marci Shimoff, #1 New York Times bestselling author


“Sweet Healing is a heart-touching and inspiring novel about holistic approaches to healing and preventing metabolic syndrome and diabetes. With vivid story-telling, Michael Bedar helps us understand the deeper meanings of wellness and healing; uplifting and potentially transformational!”

– Dr. Will Tuttle, author of the best-selling book, The World Peace Diet

results.description:
Our new winter networking event series is called Toasty Tuesday and will bring together the cannabis community for a night of networking, conversation and special guests.


Cannabis Society is hosting this winter networking event series called Toasty Tuesday with the intention to bring together the cannabis community for a night of networking, conversation and libations. Use the hashtag #ToastyTuesday when spreading the word on social media.  

We will be hosting the first Toasty event at Wink & Nod a beautiful bar in the South End of Boston. Drinks can be pricey at this location as is the seasonal food they serve so plan accordingly. We have been informed that they will have an entirely new menu of drinks and food by January 12 and we will be some of the first to try it. 

We have received word that Campaign leader Will Luzier of the Campaign to Regulate Marijuana like Alcohol in Massachusetts will be attending this event so if you have any questions about legalization in 2016 he or another official from the campaign attending can answer them.



About Wink & Nod

Located in Boston's South End, Wink & Nod embodies the good spirit of yesteryear's 

speakeasy with modern flair. Wink & Nod proudly serves an extensive list of seasonal craft cocktails, wines, beers, cordials and more – complimented by unforgettable dishes from our rotating pop-up culinary program, where visiting Chefs stage at Wink & Nod to experiment and showcase their boldest creations.

http://winkandnod.com/


Want to know about parking around Wink & Nod? Check out Boston's parking guide on Parkopedia for information.  http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/boston/


Legal Disclaimer 

Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at our local Cannabis Society community events do not necessarily express the opinion or views of the Cannabis Society organization and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors at our local events. The Cannabis Society does not distribute cannabis.

The Cannabis Society is Growing 

Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.
results.name: Toasty Tuesday

results.description:
Hello everyone,


You are invited to join us for a screening of the film "Forgotten Plague" which will be shown at our next Brighton ME/CFS/FM Support Group meeting, Tuesday Jan 12, 2016, at 6 p.m. Location is St. Margaret's Center building, Room 5, at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 736 Cambridge Street, Brighton, MA 02135,[masked]-3000. Get directions at http://www.semc.org/St-Elizabeths/Patient-and-Visitor-Information/Directions.


"Forgotten Plague" tells "the great under-reported medical story of our times." The film is an 80-minute journey into the hidden world of myalgic encephalomyelitis (chronic fatigue syndrome). It is a chilling tale of our medical system’s failures in addressing many chronic, complex diseases. Yet it is also a riveting story of science’s remarkable ability to transform medicine and improve human life itself.


This is a gripping, yet easy-to-understand story about ME/CFS, and appropriate for all audiences. We can have a short discussion after the screening. Bring a family member or friend! You will not be disappointed.


Please RSVP to [masked] if you are planning to come so we can be sure to have enough chairs in the room.See you next week,


Charmian

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
A lot of people talk about “Sales Culture”, but how does one create culture and what does a great sales culture really look like? Is there really more to it than having reps make quota?

Our guest Peter Gracey is going to share his thoughts on sales culture. As CEO of QuotaFactory and co-founder of AG Salesworks, he has seen the power of implementing a strong sales culture and how culture is the foundation of consistently stellar sales and corporate success.


ABOUT PETER


Peter Gracey is the CEO of QuotaFactory. Peter is responsible for the day-to-day operations of QuotaFactory, company growth, success, and helping clients including, sales and marketing execs to streamline their prospecting process and reach quota. Peter is also an Adjunct Professor of Sales and Marketing for the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Connect with Pete on LinkedIn and follow him on Twitter to join in on sales development discussions and industry updates.

results.name: Building a Great Sales Culture w/ Peter Gracey

results.description:
**********************************

Agenda:

**********************************

eXframe: A Semantic Web Platform for Genomics Experiments

We have developed eXframe, a Drupal-based (www.drupal.org) software for storage of genomics experimental information that publishes machine-readable data using established biomedical ontologies on the Semantic Web. Using the open-source eXframe software, institutions and laboratories can create repositories of their experiments, integrate it with heterogeneous resources and make it interoperable with the vast Web of biomedical knowledge.

Dr. Sudeshna Das is an Assistant Prof. in Neurology at the Harvard Medical School, Assistant in Neuroscience at the Mass Genral Hospital, Affiliate faculty of the Harvard Stem Cell Institute and Associate Director of the MGH Biomedical Informatics Core. She holds a Ph.D. in biomedical engineering from Boston University. After graduate school, she worked at a leading biopharmaceutical company directing computational and software development projects. There she and her colleagues developed novel approaches for statistical analysis of drug-discovery and pre-clinical data as well as large-scale software for drug discovery and development. Her current research interests include development of scientific communities, semantic web technologies, neuro-informatics and computational analysis of complex biomedical data using statistical and data-mining techniques.

results.description:
Join writer, filmmaker of "Simply Raw: Reversing Diabetes in 30 Days," Eating Behavior and Psychology researcher, Tree of Life Teacher (trained by Dr. Gabriel Cousens), and author of the new book, "Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey," Michael Bedar, for a special presentation featuring themes, tips, and practices from his newly released book, and more!

Sweet Healing:

• Inspire and teach yourself to achieve workable health goals and live in sustained vital wellness.

• Use this breathtaking new book to go on a psychological journey that instills a lasting affinity for health and well-being.

• Pick up this book as a great read or a wonderful gift that keeps on giving to friends and family this Winter!

• Bring your questions, as Michael, the author, will discuss goals, emotions, and methods of gaining wellness all portrayed in the novel he wrote on the shift from dis-ease to thriving.

Find Out Why Well-Known Leaders, and Readers Alike, are Glowing about Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey:

"The new book by Michael Bedar, Sweet Healing, touches the heart and opens the mind's eye." – Dr. Brian Clement, Director of Hippocrates Health Center

“Sweet Healing rocks! It’s a heck of an adventure for novel lovers; it’s a tale that will touch anyone who has been affected by the epidemic of diabetes and chronic disease...a gripping read of fiction that will leave you inspired, motivated, and hungry for a healthier lifestyle. Devour this book and share it with your friends now!”  – Cathy Silvers, actor from the TV sitcom, Happy Days, author of Happy Days, Healthy Living, producer of The Healthy Living Show

Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey,' offers a proven and essential alternative narrative to help you observe and identify what blocks you in life, and incorporate lifestyle practices you can use for whole-person health.” - From the Foreword by Gabriel Cousens, MD, MD(H) author of Rainbow Green Live-Food Cuisine, Conscious Eating, and There Is a Cure for Diabetes


“Sweet Healing is filled with Michael’s dedication, caring, and generous personality, infused with serving and raising awareness for the world around him as if it were his own family. In this book you’ll find a great story to help avail yourself to wisdom and knowledge about eating and living a healthier lifestyle. A story written like this comes from someone walking his talk. Sweet Healing is inspiring to those suffering with preventable and reversible illnesses, so they may create new habits and ways of living that reinforce a loving, healthy sense of self.” – Debbie Merrill, US Figure Skating Silver-Medalist, author of Raw Truth to the Fountain of Youth, host of the Debbie Merrill Show

“For people searching, this book is a parable about waking up and getting your spark back par excellence! I heartily and excitedly recommend Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey as a boon to those who want to find out what’s possible in the realm of their well-being. Read it on a plane, in bed, in a book club, or on your train commute–just READ it!” – Nomi Shannon, Author of What Do Raw Fooders Eat 1 & 2, The Raw Gourmet, and Raw Food Celebrations

Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey now. It is an indispensable parable. It will take you on a possible journey to better health and a life empowered by positive choices, informed by proven research and presented as an entertaining read." – Mike Adams, the Health Ranger, editor of NaturalNews.com

"Sweet Healing - A Whole Health Journey is a 'Way of the Peaceful Warrior' and 'Celestine Prophecy'-type adventure for today's epidemic times." - Annie Padden Jubb, author of Secrets of an Alkaline Body, owner of LifeFood Restaurant Chain LA

“If you know someone who’s faced with type 2 diabetes or a degenerative metabolic health crisis, I highly recommend this inspirational novel! In Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey, the characters demonstrate how each small step in the process of healing builds upon itself. This book inspires readers to take a proactive approach to their healing and offers innovative tips for health, happiness, and longevity.” – Marci Shimoff, #1 New York Times bestselling author

“Sweet Healing is a heart-touching and inspiring novel about holistic approaches to healing and preventing metabolic syndrome and diabetes. With vivid storytelling, Michael Bedar helps us understand the deeper meanings of wellness and healing; uplifting and potentially transformational!” – Dr. Will Tuttle, author of the best-selling book, The World Peace Diet 

“This book was amazing. Michael Bedar’s expertise in his field of holistic healing is surpassed only by the dedication and love he has for serving people. Sweet Healing is a kaleidoscopic journey into the little known (until now) subject of naturally recovering from type 2 diabetes. If you are diabetic or know someone who is, read this book, and awaken into wellness. It just may save your life.” – Frank Ferrante, subject of the award-winning documentary, May I Be Frank, and author of the book, May I Be Frank

“'Sweet Healing' lays out a framework that can guide us all back to using food and movement as the most powerful tools to maintain our health and vitality. I use this book as a trusted resource with all of my patients diagnosed with diabetes and other degenerative diseases.” – Harry McIlroy, MD, Integrative Physician

Sweet Healing takes you on an inspiring whole health journey that frees you to enjoy every day of your life. Get life-altering inspiration and everyday practices to transform and sustain your wellness using this breathtaking new book to go on a psychological, physical, and soulful journey that is proven to leave you with a lasting affinity for healthy living now! 
​

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
Location: Amazon, 101 Main st., 6th Floor, Cambridge, MA 02142

This is an RSVP event. Please come prepared to identify with your Meetup account. Thank you to the Amazon team, and specifically Ricardo DeMatos, who has helped make these venue arrangements.


Thank you to Logz.io, Asaf Yigal, who is arranging food sponsorship and a presentation. 

Presentation: Lessons Learned in Deploying the ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana)


Setting up the increasingly-popular open-source ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana) on AWS might seem like an easy task, but we have gone through several iterations in our architecture and have made some mistakes in our deployments that have turned out to be common in the industry. In this talk, we will go through what we did and explain what worked and what failed -- and why.

Presenter: Asaf Yigal with Logz.io

Agenda:
6:30-7:00 Food and networking
7:00-7:45 (presentation)
8:00-9:00 (presentation)


Contact Mark Annati, the moderator, at [masked] with interest in presenting. Thank you.

results.description:
Peter Beshai, @pbesh, Basketball Systems Analyst for the Boston Celtics. Peter is the creator of Buckets, an insanely rich visualization of Basketball stats. He uses Linked Hilighting heavily to cross-correlate different charts with a Flux architecture. Blog post: https://medium.com/@pbesh/linked-highlighting-with-react-d3-js-and-reflux-16e9c0b2210b#.dnaxaxn25

Kevin Robinson, @krob, will present an adaptation of a talk from React Europe this summer and some updates.


First, we'll share how user experience choices are a primary influence on how we design the data layer, especially for teams developing new products with full-stack capabilities.  Working with data from multiple backend services has powerful benefits, and shapes the problem space for UI engineering.


Next, we'll look how designs like decoupling 'recording facts' from 'computing views of those facts' have influenced UI engineering.  These designs nudge teams towards simplicity when creating impactful user-facing improvements like real-time updates, optimistic commits, and graceful handling of network outages.
results.name: Visualize the NBA, simplify the Data Layer

Fitness trackers and apps are one of the fastest growing segments of the outdoors industry.  And for good reason! They allow you to monitor and improve your performance, or just get a snapshot of how active you are.

下午6点到晚上8点3

PLEASE (try to) request by 4 pm the day before the Tuesday evening event.

* Harvard Square to LMA is about 30 minutes on #66 bus or M2 Harvard bus
* Green Line E-Line comes to Brigham Circle, then walk BACK to crosswalk, then to the building
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, via Tremont Street to Brigham Circle
* Walking from Brookline is about 10 minutes - via Huntington Avenue or Longwood Avenue
* MFA, NEU, Wentworth, and Colleges of the Fenway are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue

* Street parking is FREE from 6 pm onward (but not always easy to find)

you may wish to ask the HCSPH security guard how to access Kresge 201

PLEASE plan to show up early so we can begin our 'bilingual introductions' on time, so our presenter can begin (and end) on time.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

When and what time is Obama delivering the 2016 State of the Union?
President Obama’s final State of the Union (SOTU) Address will be on Tuesday, January 12 at 9:00 p.m. EST. While the date is earlier than normal (the speech has typically been delivered the following Tuesday), the setting is the same as always: the House Chamber at the U.S. Capitol, which saw congressional addresses from Pope Francis and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in 2015. Obama’s State of the Union speeches have typically lasted about an hour.

How can I watch this year’s SOTU?
All major networks and cable news channels will broadcast the speech live. Other forms of streaming will be available, including by video at whitehouse.gov and on the radio through NPR.

What topics will he cover in this year’s speech?

In a preview to the address, Obama promised to frame his speech around “the big things” in “the years to come.” The speech promises to be less policy-heavy and more big-picture, outlining what Obama sees as his lasting achievements. With more attention to his record, the White House sees the address as a chance to tout arguments Obama has already made, especially those related to the environment and trade. The president can also use the newly released job report as evidence of the economic recovery he’s shepherded. After a rare live televised town hall event on guns last Thursday, he can continue his use of the bully pulpit to push for a broad movement against gun violence. Obama is known as a rigorous editor of his own address.

What issues are on the minds of voters? 
While terrorism risks have dominated the national conversation after the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, immigration and general dissatisfaction with the government have proven themselves higher-polling issues. Yet a fear of terrorism is still prevalent and manifold: almost half the country worries a family member will be a victim of an attack. Americans are also increasingly in favor of executive action on guns, as a recent CNN poll has demonstrated. And as usual, the economy reigns: economists believe America is close to full employment, but resentment over wages and income inequality has still dominated this election cycle.

</a> <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/2016-state-of-the-union-michelle-obama-first-lady-guests-217537">First lady's State of the Union guests are nod to Obama's campaigns, nation's progress

By KRISTEN EAST

On a less issue-specific note: Michelle Obama’s style statements at past State of the Union speeches have given fashion-minded viewers plenty to discuss.

How will the presidential election feature in the address? 
The clear implication in the White House’s preview to the address is that a Democratic agenda — one that would be carried forth by front-runner Hillary Clinton — is positioning the country for continued growth over the next decade. Obama has mostly alluded to Republican candidates in the past few months and has abstained from endorsing a Democratic candidate. He hasmentioned he would have had fun running against Donald Trump.

Will a Supreme Court justice fall asleep on camera again? 
A buzzed-about moment of the address in 2015 was Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg appearing to doze off in the audience. She later admitted she wasn’t “100 percent sober” because of some “very fine California wine” Justice Anthony Kennedy brought to a dinner before the speech.

Who’s sitting behind the president?
This is new House Speaker Paul Ryan’s first time sitting behind Obama. The two have a complicated relationship, and Ryan recently said he thinks Donald Trump would make a better president. Perhaps more importantly: this is likely Vice President and amateur comedian Joe Biden’s final SOTU address; he has regularly starred in broadcasts of the speech as a finger gun-pointingGIF machine.

Who are the key guests at the State of the Union?
Top Democrats have encouraged their colleagues to bring Muslim-Americans to the address to display the party’s open-mindedness after Trump proposed to ban Muslims from entering the United States. Rep. Pete Aguilar of California is bringing two top law enforcement officials at the center of the San Bernardino terrorist attack. Sen. Al Franken is bringing a Somali-American deli owner from Minnesota. Republican Rep. Elise Stefanik of New York plans to bring the first female commandant of West Point. Michigan Reps. Justin Amash and Debbie Dingell are bringing University of Michigan football coach Jim Harbaugh. Rep. Bob Dold of Illinois had to disinvite his guest after accusations of domestic abuse were uncovered shortly after Dold announced his invitation. Michelle Obama, meanwhile, will leave one seat in her box empty "for the victims of gun violence who no longer have a voice," the White House said. Other seats in the first lady's box will be occupied by Edith Childs of Greenwood, South Carolina, and Earl Smith of Austin, Texas. Childs, a Greenwood County councilor, is known for her “Fired up! Ready to go!” chant that became an unofficial slogan of Obama’s 2008 and 2012 campaigns. Smith gave Obama in February 2008 a military patch he wore while serving in Vietnam. The patch struck a chord with Obama, and the then-presidential candidate carried it in his pocket throughout his campaign. The first lady will also host Jim Obergefell, who was the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case that legalized same-sex marriage; Refaai Hamo, a Syrian refugee living in Troy, Michigan; and Spencer Stone, who helped prevent an attack on a Paris-bound train last year; among others.

Who’s delivering the GOP response?
Long seen as a rising star in the GOP and as a potential vice presidential pick, South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley will give the brief post-address response. The youngest governor in America and the third consecutive woman to deliver the response, Haley has promised to deliver a more upbeat set of remarks.

</a> <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/white-house-releases-annotated-versions-of-past-sotu-addresses-217536">White House to annotate State of the Union address

By KRISTEN EAST

Where is Obama going after the State of the Union?
Obama is visiting two states after the speech: Nebraska and Louisiana. On Wednesday in Omaha he’ll highlight the state’s job growth and embrace of his health care law. The White House is also promoting Obama’s “historic investment in college affordability.” Nebraska has seen a 95 percent increase in Pell Grant funding. On Thursday in Baton Rouge — his 10th visit to Louisiana since taking office — he’ll discuss the state’s efforts to expand Medicaid and its attention to early childhood education. Almost $10 million have been invested in preschool development grants in the state.

Read more: 

http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/state-of-union-2016-obama-217511#ixzz3x4k6NUu2

results.description:
Hi everyone,  welcome to 2016!


Mark your calendars for our January meetup on Tues Jan 12th. We will be joined by Tesora as our co-sponsor and we will explore OpenStack and database as a service technologies with project Trove. 


OpenStack Trove is the Database-as-a-Service project in OpenStack and provides a simple way to provision and operate a number of different databases in an OpenStack cloud. Trove provides methods to manage these databases throughout their lifecycle and perform operations like backup and restore, configure and operate complex topologies like replication and clustering, and manage the configuration settings of these databases. Trove currently supports relational databases like MySQL (including MariaDB and Percona), PostgreSQL, and Vertica, and NoSQL databases like MongoDB, Cassandra, Couchbase, CouchDB, and Redis.

An important aspect of Trove is that it is easy to add support for a new database and in this talk we illustrate how one can add support for a new database in Trove using the example of Apache HBase. In this presentation, we describe the architecture of Trove and the actual code changes required to add support for Apache HBase in Trove and demonstrate a simple Apache HBase database orchestrated by Trove.

Reminders:

• A light dinner and soft drinks will be provided courtesy of Tesora ~ 6:15pm and we will kick off the sessions ~ 7:00pm.

• If you are interested in giving a Lightening Talk shoot us a note with a topic or just come to the session ready to speak!

• DON'T FORGET - for security reasons, the NERD center requires attendees to show a government issued photo ID in order to gain access into the building.

• Parking: Best option for parking is the NERD center parking garage which charges a flat rate after 4pm.
results.name: OpenStack and data bases!

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

THE HAPPINESS OF CONTENTMENT                                                                                                      a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | JANUARY 5th - 26th


7:00 - 8:30pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

In our search for happiness, we use our time and energy seeking so many different things. We may change our job, our partner, our home, our situation, but we will never know real satisfaction until we change our restless, discontented mind. The mind of attachment is the main cause of our discontentment, relationship difficulties and craving.

In this drop-in meditation series we will learn practical methods and meditations that enable us to let go of attachment and find peace in all of our circumstances. Life doesn’t always go as planned but through the practice of contentment we can learn to keep a happy mind in all situations.

Drop in anytime! No need to pre-registration. 

Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

Beat Brasserie (aka Beat Hôtel) is an American restaurant and bar located in the heart of Harvard Square. Opened by the team behind The Beehive, the wildly popular eatery and bar in Boston's South End, Beat Brasserie offers a fresh, seasonal menu, enjoyable by carnivores and vegetarians alike. Our bar celebrates American spirits, beer and features over 35 American artisanal wines by the glass or carafe on our state-of-the-art wine tap system. Whether you have public speaking anxiety or simply want to express yourself with greater clarity the experience in a Speaking Circle® will guide you toward effortless authenticity

Speaking Circles help:

Business professionals become more effective, authentic and powerful. 

People expand their vision of what life could be like when they are able to

be fully present, confident and authentic. 

People who suffer from stage fright to overcome their fears.

Hope to see you soon,

Dexter Nardella

At a Speaking Circle you are provided all the support you need to express yourself in your own time and in your own unique way, without fear or discomfort. Some call this depth of expression, “speaking from the heart,” “the authentic self” or “your real voice.” Whatever you call it, you know when you are there; you know when someone else is there.  Click to read FAQs about a Speaking Circle.  

http://www.speakingcirclesinternational.com/Articles/Principles/FAQ.html#.VKx9y0c76rU

See and hear participants talk about their experience in SPEAKING CIRCLES: http://youtu.be/Wi82ZIgioh0

results.description:
For January we're reading DMZ by Brian Wood. We're doing the first 12 issues, or book 1. Thanks to Rob for the recommendation, it sounds wacky.


Logistical thing to mention: at the past couple meetups, waffling about exactly how many people were coming has made things a little awkward with the staff at the Friendly toast. If you're running late but are still going to make it, drop us a line on this event page, otherwise when they ask us how many people we have we won't count you!


The Bumf:

In the near future, America's worst nightmare has come true. With military adventurism overseas bogging down the Army and National Guard, the U.S. government mistakenly neglects the very real threat of anti-establishment militias scattered across the 50 states. Like a sleeping giant, Middle America rises up and violently pushes its way to the shining seas, coming to a standstill at the line in the sand -- Manhattan or, as the world now knows it, the DMZ.


If you plan on coming, once you've read the book please post one discussion question in the comments for this event. I'll bring a list of them with me, and as usual we'll have them there to draw from when we're looking for stuff to talk about. I won't turn you away if you don't, but let's make running these things a group effort!

For those who haven't been to the Comic Book Club before, it's pretty simple - we sit around, order some food and some drink, and we probe deep into the merits and meanings of our chosen book or books. I also bring along a list of questions (written by you!) to give the discussion a bit of structure - but don't worry - it's pretty casual!

The venue is the Friendly Toast, which is a very casual kinda place with plenty of room where we can easily be heard. Please note though, that it's best to bring cash - although supposedly their card minimum has been relaxed - perhaps even obliterated!
results.how_to_find_us: We gather on the couches in the front beforehand, and once we have a quorum we get a table -- usually one of the booths or the tables in the very back if it's a large group. Ask the staff if you can't find us!
results.name: DMZ by Brian Wood

The folks in our group share a common journey of waking up to our interconnection with life around us. Please join us.  No experience with the Work That Reconnects is required, though if you do have experience that is great.  Periodically there are 1-day experiential trainings in the Boston area we can connect you with (a couple scheduled for November).

Our Work That Reconnects Praxis Group meets once a month on a weekday evening from 7-9pm.  Our first meeting was in September...so we are a relatively new group and welcome newcomers.

results.description:
What if how we make and hold agreements has an enormous impact on our happiness and our success?   What if we unwittingly and unnecessarily undermine our goals?  What if we could follow simple rules to make agreements that increase our success and happiness?


Come and explore the theory and practice of making, keeping, and leveraging agreements -- Insight style.  

- Why are agreements so important?
- What are the automatic costs of breaking agreements?
- What are the automatic benefits of keeping agreements?
- What is the relationship between agreements and personal integrity?
- What does breaking an agreement mean -- to others? to yourself?
- How can you make agreements such that you always remain in integrity?
- What happens when you just can't keep an agreement? What does "can't" really mean?

We'll review concepts from Insight, reprise an exercise, fashion a few new exercises to practice the careful, conscious crafting of agreements, and augment with insights from other sources. 

We will walk away with greater ability to keep our word, enjoying the powerful benefits in joy and success from living a life more fully in integrity.


About the Insight Practice Group
Insight Practice Groups are open to everyone -- to Insight graduates and to non-graduates alike. The only requirement is that you come ready to examine what a better life for yourself might be, and willing to do something to create it.

The Insight Practice Group is an open, informal gathering of like-hearted people who would like to explore, share, practice, and extend some of the lessons that Insight (not uniquely, but powerfully) introduces in their seminars. We reprise exercises, apply them to our current life, examine how to better put our results into practice, and augment the lessons with other sources of wisdom.

Disclaimer: These sessions are led by untrained volunteers like you, some of whom have taken Insight and some of whom have not.  Insight Practice Groups are inspired by, but not associated with, Insight Seminars.
results.name: IPG-128S: The Theory, Practice, & Importance of Agreements

In this meditation, you can do your favorite silent meditation--perhaps mindfulness of breath or ambient sound. 

But we'll warm up with some exercises to remind us to relax the muscles around the mouth and eyes. I'll discuss some scientific research that suggests that relaxing the eye muscles can reduce mental imagery and that relaxing the muscles used in speech can quiet the inner voice.

After the meditation, we'll have a discussion. 

If there is interest, we'll go out afterwards for a bite to each afterwards in Harvard Square.


Also, you might be interested in this Naked Diner podcast I did on Secular Meditation.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
