results.description:
We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.



Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

results.description:
President Obama's FINAL State of the Union (SOTU) Address
at 9:00 pm EST

President Obama's FINAL State of the Union (SOTU) Address
will be widely-broadcast (on TV, radio, or the Internet) .

The President speaks English quite well!
For that reason, and for several others, he's worth watching!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


When and what time is Obama delivering the 2016 State of the Union?
President Obama’s final State of the Union (SOTU) Address will be on Tuesday, January 12 at 9:00 p.m. EST. While the date is earlier than normal (the speech has typically been delivered the following Tuesday), the setting is the same as always: the House Chamber at the U.S. Capitol, which saw congressional addresses from Pope Francis and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in 2015. Obama’s State of the Union speeches have typically lasted about an hour.

How can I watch this year’s SOTU?
All major networks and cable news channels will broadcast the speech live. Other forms of streaming will be available, including by video at whitehouse.gov and on the radio through NPR.

What topics will he cover in this year’s speech?


In a preview to the address, Obama promised to frame his speech around “the big things” in “the years to come.” The speech promises to be less policy-heavy and more big-picture, outlining what Obama sees as his lasting achievements. With more attention to his record, the White House sees the address as a chance to tout arguments Obama has already made, especially those related to the environment and trade. The president can also use the newly released job report as evidence of the economic recovery he’s shepherded. After a rare live televised town hall event on guns last Thursday, he can continue his use of the bully pulpit to push for a broad movement against gun violence. Obama is known as a rigorous editor of his own address.

What issues are on the minds of voters? 
While terrorism risks have dominated the national conversation after the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, immigration and general dissatisfaction with the government have proven themselves higher-polling issues. Yet a fear of terrorism is still prevalent and manifold: almost half the country worries a family member will be a victim of an attack. Americans are also increasingly in favor of executive action on guns, as a recent CNN poll has demonstrated. And as usual, the economy reigns: economists believe America is close to full employment, but resentment over wages and income inequality has still dominated this election cycle.

</a> <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/2016-state-of-the-union-michelle-obama-first-lady-guests-217537">First lady's State of the Union guests are nod to Obama's campaigns, nation's progress By KRISTEN EAST

On a less issue-specific note: Michelle Obama’s style statements at past State of the Union speeches have given fashion-minded viewers plenty to discuss.

How will the presidential election feature in the address? 
The clear implication in the White House’s preview to the address is that a Democratic agenda — one that would be carried forth by front-runner Hillary Clinton — is positioning the country for continued growth over the next decade. Obama has mostly alluded to Republican candidates in the past few months and has abstained from endorsing a Democratic candidate. He hasmentioned he would have had fun running against Donald Trump.

Will a Supreme Court justice fall asleep on camera again? 
A buzzed-about moment of the address in 2015 was Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg appearing to doze off in the audience. She later admitted she wasn’t “100 percent sober” because of some “very fine California wine” Justice Anthony Kennedy brought to a dinner before the speech.

Who’s sitting behind the president?
This is new House Speaker Paul Ryan’s first time sitting behind Obama. The two have a complicated relationship, and Ryan recently said he thinks Donald Trump would make a better president. Perhaps more importantly: this is likely Vice President and amateur comedian Joe Biden’s final SOTU address; he has regularly starred in broadcasts of the speech as a finger gun-pointingGIF machine.

Who are the key guests at the State of the Union?
Top Democrats have encouraged their colleagues to bring Muslim-Americans to the address to display the party’s open-mindedness after Trump proposed to ban Muslims from entering the United States. Rep. Pete Aguilar of California is bringing two top law enforcement officials at the center of the San Bernardino terrorist attack. Sen. Al Franken is bringing a Somali-American deli owner from Minnesota. Republican Rep. Elise Stefanik of New York plans to bring the first female commandant of West Point. Michigan Reps. Justin Amash and Debbie Dingell are bringing University of Michigan football coach Jim Harbaugh. Rep. Bob Dold of Illinois had to disinvite his guest after accusations of domestic abuse were uncovered shortly after Dold announced his invitation. Michelle Obama, meanwhile, will leave one seat in her box empty "for the victims of gun violence who no longer have a voice," the White House said. Other seats in the first lady's box will be occupied by Edith Childs of Greenwood, South Carolina, and Earl Smith of Austin, Texas. Childs, a Greenwood County councilor, is known for her “Fired up! Ready to go!” chant that became an unofficial slogan of Obama’s 2008 and 2012 campaigns. Smith gave Obama in February 2008 a military patch he wore while serving in Vietnam. The patch struck a chord with Obama, and the then-presidential candidate carried it in his pocket throughout his campaign. The first lady will also host Jim Obergefell, who was the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case that legalized same-sex marriage; Refaai Hamo, a Syrian refugee living in Troy, Michigan; and Spencer Stone, who helped prevent an attack on a Paris-bound train last year; among others.

Who’s delivering the GOP response?
Long seen as a rising star in the GOP and as a potential vice presidential pick, South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley will give the brief post-address response. The youngest governor in America and the third consecutive woman to deliver the response, Haley has promised to deliver a more upbeat set of remarks.

</a> <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/white-house-releases-annotated-versions-of-past-sotu-addresses-217536">White House to annotate State of the Union address By KRISTEN EAST

Where is Obama going after the State of the Union?
Obama is visiting two states after the speech: Nebraska and Louisiana. On Wednesday in Omaha he’ll highlight the state’s job growth and embrace of his health care law. The White House is also promoting Obama’s “historic investment in college affordability.” Nebraska has seen a 95 percent increase in Pell Grant funding. On Thursday in Baton Rouge — his 10th visit to Louisiana since taking office — he’ll discuss the state’s efforts to expand Medicaid and its attention to early childhood education. Almost $10 million have been invested in preschool development grants in the state.

Read more:  http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/state-of-union-2016-obama-217511#ixzz3x4k6NUu2
results.name: President Obama's FINAL State of the Union (SOTU) Address

 TOPIC: How to use Net Promoter Score to improve customer satisfaction

ORGANIZER: Markedu - Alexander Andersen - Twitter @markedu

Used by companies of all sizes, Net Promoter Score® (NPS) has become one of the most popular methods to measure customer satisfaction. In this webinar, J. Christian Andersen will show you how NPS will help you improve customer experience and get more customers to recommend your business to others.

Why attend this webinar:

1. Introduction to Net Promoter Score® methodology – used by top brands such as LEGO, Apple and businesses of all sizes.

2. The 5 steps to Customer Nirvana that have become the touchstone and blueprint for everything we do.

3. Codifying LEGO and other world brands in the search for excellence. You will see exactly what to copy and how to apply it.

More information about the speakers:

Relationwise - J.Christian Andersen - CEO - Twitter @BeRelationwise

J. Christian Andersen is the co-founder of Relationwise and author of two books. He has presented numerous talks and workshops and advised leaders on how to make their company the one people love to recommend. Lately one of his customers said; “I highly recommend Christian. In just one hour we received the necessary, unconventional advice we needed in order for us to get started in mobilizing our customer ambassadors.”

ADDED INSTRUCTIONS ON HOW TO REGISTER

venue.name: American Red Cross of Massachusetts Bay Food Pantry

results.description:
American Red Cross Boston Food Pantry provides a 5-day emergency supply of food once a month to low-income clients- about 105k annually or 400- 500 families per distribution day- making it one of the largest food pantries in New England.

The Wednesday Food Distribution event includes preparing 'wet' bags of perishable food, assisting clients with the intake process, i.e. translation of languages(Chinese,Creole, ESL,Russian, Portuguese, Vietnamese, Spanish, etc), carrying food bags out of the pantry for clients to their cars, etc.

Expectations:

Ability to lift 25lbs. and stand for 3+ hours

In cold weather dress warmly b/c work in & outside pantry can be vry cold!

Dressing 'comfortable' but no cut off shorts, mini skirts, half shirts, open-toed shoes/sandals, please!

Ability to take direction willingly and to work comfortably in a diverse environment.

While the Food Pantry shares the building with Liquor Land, Fastenal and The Hen House, the actual entrance is on Proctor St. or in the rear of the building, not on Mass Ave. There IS parking! It is very limited behind the pantry, past Liquorland's lot. There is parking on Procter St. across from the entrance to the pantry. On corner of Mass Ave. + Procter St. there is a parking lot, via Magazine St.
results.how_to_find_us: The closest T stop to the food pantry is Andrew Square Station on the Red Line. The #10 bus runs from Andrew Square to 1010 Mass. Ave. across the street from the food pantry.
results.name: Help distribute food at The American Red Cross Boston Food Pantry

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Further, Kumesh Aroomoogan, CEO of Accern will provide background on how he and his team process millions of news articles to generate the underlying data used for the strategy.

Hope you can join us!

Kelly

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

Vegan Cooking Classes or  
Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food
(using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 


What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food.

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
For this operation, there are "No qualifications - no limits!"
We have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.

Make us busy - very busy.

Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

Hey, it's Josh

Don't you like helping people? 

Wouldn't you like to easily meet new people? 

Are you inherently a team leader? 

The Boston Volunteers, the well respected 501c3 nonprofit, is actively seeking two dedicated leaders to join our team. 

This is a great opportunity for you if you: 

1. Like organizing events

2. yearn to help more people

3. want to easily meet new people

As many of you know, we have more than 8,300+ Boston Volunteers. Most of our events fill up immediately and have long waiting lists. We need you!

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org

We play Settlers of Catan, Ticket to Ride, Munchkin, and may others.

 Got a game you want to play? Bring it, we are willing to learn and if we can work it into the rotation we will.

Otherwise just bring the ability to forgive the robber for stealing your sheep.

The ability to overlook how the other Munchkin players have stopped you from getting past level 9 ten times in a row and suddenly your down to level 8. Just breath, in and out, in and out.

Recent lesson learned: Never pull a ticket for NY to LA when another player only has 8 trains left. Keep those eyes open.

results.description:
We are pleased to announce we are starting the new year with a great speaker lineup!

Richard Tibbetts is a visiting scientist at MIT and leads the open source project for BayesDB -  The MIT Probabilistic Computing Project. Prior to work on BayesDB, Tibbetts founded StreamBase, a successful Complex Event Processing platform that combined SQL-style analytics with real-time streaming data. His interests include programming languages, human-computer interaction, software safety, distributed architectures, and streaming analytics.

To know more about Richard and read his thoughts and ideas, visit his website. ( Click Here) 

6:00 PM to 6:30 PM - Networking

6:30 to 8PM - Talk and Q&A

Talk Title: BayesDB: Query the Probable Implications of Your Data

Prerequisite: Familiarity with SQL and data manipulation.

Abstract: Statistics and machine learning are part of many new systems, but have been described as the “high interest credit card of technical debt.” Is it possible to make statistical inference broadly accessible to non-statistician programmers without sacrificing mathematical rigor or inference quality? BayesDB is a system that enables users to query the probably implications of their data as directly as SQL enables them to query the data itself.

BayesDB abstracts away model-specific details of statistical inference by providing a declarative query language, BQL. The Bayesian Query Language extends SQL and provides queries for Bayesian data analysis that are answered by averaging over an implicit space of probabilistic models. BayesDB provides a machine-assisted modeling language, MML, that enables domain experts to specify qualitative constraints and produces baseline models that are suitable for data cleaning, anomaly detection, variable selection, and a broad class of prediction tasks. BayesDB also provides an extensible interface for plugging in statistical and algorithmic models and composing multiple kinds of models into a single population.

This presentation focuses on the applications of BayesDB to analyzing and understanding developmental economics data in collaboration with the Gates Foundation. BayesDB’s domain-general metamodel and extensible architecture have been successfully applied to understand financial services fraud, microbiome data, clinical data from a study of diabetes, earth satellites, and astronomy.

Click here to learn more about BayesDB
results.name: BayesDB: Query the Probable Implications of Your Data

results.description:
Boston Traders' Meetup

You are invited to attend the monthly Boston Traders' Meetup meetings.

The format for the monthly meetings is that each person will introduce her- or himself and state the market that he or she trades and perhaps a very brief description of the approach taken. For example, an introduction could be, "Hi, my name is Fred Hampton and I trade forex breakouts during the London session."

From there, the floor is open for people to discuss anything about trading. You may talk about something you learned recently about trading or about an obstacle that you are facing in trading or make a request for resources from other members.

Please print out and bring this BostonTradersMeetup sign so you can connect with the other members easily.
www.meetup.com/BostonTraders/files/

Part of the purpose of this group is for people to connect with other traders so it's encouraged for people to exchange contact info. For example, if you are an options trader and another options trader talks about a topic that interests you, then feel free to ask the person if she or he would like to exchange contact info.

--------------------


This meeting is located in the Starbucks inside what is called the "Boston Marriott" even though the hotel is located in Kendall Square, Cambridge. The Kendall Square subway stop is a Red Line stop at "Kendall."

This meeting is FREE and it repeats on the 2nd Wednesday of every month.

results.description:
Hi everyone!

Happy New Year!!

At our January 13 Monthly Meeting, our speaker - Robin Goldsmith - will be providing insights into defining requirements as tests...

Topic: Tips and Traps of Defining Requirements as Tests


Abstract:
Agile development did not invent but surely popularized using tests as a way to define requirements.  Various forms of Agile test-driven development have been found valuable.  Tests have the advantage of being more concrete and specific than many requirements are.  Tests also can be executed to demonstrate that a requirement has been met; and writing the test may allow not having to also document the requirement it tests. Robin describes these and additional ways/benefits of defining requirements with tests.  He also reveals and examines less-recognized but vitally critical issues, including effect on requirements and products when tests (too typically) are defined inadequately and paradoxical implications of testing a requirement that is defined as a test.

•  Types of tests that clarify or even constitute the requirements
•  Ways to reduce requirements impacts when tests are defined inadequately
•  How defining requirements as tests diminishes test effectiveness


Speaker Bio:

Robin F. Goldsmith, JD is President of the Software Quality Group of New England and Needham consultancy Go Pro Management, Inc.  He advises and trains business and systems professional on risk-based Proactive Software Quality Assurance and Testing™, REAL requirements, REAL ROI™, metrics, outsourcing, project and process management.  He author of the book, Discovering REAL Business Requirements for Software Project Success, and the forthcoming book, Cut Creep:  Put Business Back in Business Analysis to Discover REAL Business Requirements for Agile, ATDD, and Other Project Success.

results.description:
Clustering SQL Server still vexes many in one way or another. For some, it is even worse now that both AlwaysOn features - clustered instances (FCIs) and availability groups (AGs) - require an underlying Windows Server failover cluster. Storage, networking, Active Directory quorum, and more are topics that come up quite often. Learn from one of the world's experts on clustering SQL Server some the most important items - both good and bad - that you need to do to be successful whether you are creating an FCI, AG, or combining both together in one solution.

SQLHA founder, Microsoft Cluster MVP, and SQL Server mission critical expert Allan Hirt (@SQLHA)is a consultant, published author, speaker, and trainer who has been using Microsoft SQL Server in various guises since 1992 since interning at Sybase in college. Based in the Boston, MA area, he travels all over the world to work with and train clients. Allan is currently working on the book Mission Critical SQL Server.

Our opening lightning talk will be done by Tim Roberts.
results.name: Top 10 Clustering Dos and Don'ts - Allan Hirt

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

results.description:
Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

results.description: In this classic HI USA workshop, with a fresh twist, you'll learn the basics of traveling solo. You'll walk away with the confidence and skills to get there and away, stay in hostels and how to adapt a basic credo around respect and approaching unique situations. Workshop leader and avid hosteller Leah Moschella will share time-tested skills, safety pointers, and general travel resources on how to get the most out of your travel experience. Additionally, she'll share tips, tricks and practical advice from her own travels on what works best for solo female travelers. This workshop will be interactive and include exercises and discussions about solo travel experiences, itinerary planning and mapping out the basics. By the end, you should feel comfortable and ready to get out there and start your first solo journey!

results.description:
Part of our growth in dismantling racism and its intersections is making mistakes and becoming accountable to them.  This includes acknowledging the harm that we caused while making efforts to learn from the experience.  But, sometimes we f#%k up painfully.  We hurt others, and sometimes that hurt is irrevocable.  Sometimes in calling out other people’s sh#t, we do not realize the role that our own sh#t is playing.  Sometimes in calling someone out, we make mistakes that make the situation worse than if we had done nothing.

In this real talk session, we will dig into our most painful mistakes in doing intersectional anti-racist work.  This will not be an easy session, at least if we are doing it right. This will not be a space to make ourselves look good.  This is a space to own up to our f#%k-ups and try really hard to grow from them together as a community.  

Our discussion will start from the following questions:

• What were our most painful f#%k-ups?  Who did we hurt most in the process?

• How do we own up to our biggest f#%k-ups?

• How do we remain accountable to those we hurt, even if they no longer want anything to do with us?

• Are there times when we sort of did the right thing but it went badly so that it now feels like a f#%k-up?

• How do the memories of our f#%k-ups hold us back?

• How can the memories of our f#%k-ups help us work toward intersectional racial justice?

Content note:  Many of the experiences that get retold in this discussion will involve direct complicity in racism, sexism, cissexism, heterosexism, and/or ableism.  This discussion may therefore involve topics that could end up being hurtful or triggering.

Accessibility Information: Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The fourth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.
results.how_to_find_us: When you get to 14 Beacon Street, dial # and 19 (this will call the phone and we will buzz you in). Go to the 4th floor (you can either take the elevator up or walk up the stairs). The space is to your left, at the back of the building.
results.name: Real Talk: The times we f#%ked up

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
Hiking the Alta Via Valle D’Aosta in the Italian Alps

Potluck 6:30pm, Slideshow 7:15pm


Tucked in the northwestern corner of Italy next to Switzerland and France is a trekking route through incomparable scenery.  The Alta Via (“High Road”) circles the Valle D’Aosta on the flanks of the highest peaks in Europe including Mt Blanc, the Matterhorn, Monte Rosa, and Gran Paradiso. Part of the route traverses the high peaks of Gran Paradiso (“Paradise”) National park, one of that largest in Europe, famous for its rare alpine flora and fauna including herds of Ibex and Chamois, in addition to absolutely stunning mountain peaks. Join us as Pam Wilmot shows photos from the trip she has led on the Alta Via  2 for the AMC’s Adventure Travel Committee this past August.

Potluck Info: Participation in the potlucks is optional, yet useful for that  post-office work hunger. Homemade dishes are welcome, store bought goodies & takeout are equally welcome. Plates, bowls, cups, cutlery, napkins and drink pitchers will be supplied. The auditorium has a kitchen if you need to do any re-warming or prep (stovetop, oven, microwave, sink & fridge). Please bring your own cooking pots if needed for stovetop. Potlucks start at 6:30pm.

Subway Directions: Take the MBTA to Park Street Station. Walk through the Boston Common uphill towards the State House on Beacon St. To the left of the State House is Joy St; follow Joy St uphill to the AMC Auditorium Building (brownstone), #4 Joy St on the left hand side. Map: http://tinyurl.com/4JoyStMap

Parking: Nearby parking is available at the Boston Common Garage, located underneath the Boston Common. Access is off Charles St, between the Public Garden and the Boston Common. We sell discount parking passes  ($9 each). You'll save 50%! More info about the Garage is here:  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/boston-boston-common-garage-zero-charles-street-parking.html#Tab_coupon-rates
results.name: Hiking the Alta Via Valle D’Aosta, Potluck & Slideshow

More Great Speeches: Wed, Jan 13.  - Don't let your speaking abilities hold you back this year.

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]

results.description:
Our first event of the new year!   

Rick Landwehr will be leading this LovingKindness meditation.   Our event start time is 6:45pm.  But please arrive early to settle in.  

Our schedule:
6:30pm -  It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat.  We have chitchat time starting around 6:30. Come hang out with us and feel free to peruse the store. 
6:45pm - Class starts.
Please note: We lock the door at 7pm.  At 7pm, you are already 15 minutes late for class, so please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking. 
8:00pm - Class ends.

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
            1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness
            2) instructions on how to meditate
            3) an experience of a lovingkindness meditation
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand.


More info:
Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights.  
 http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/ 

What to bring:
It's fine to just show up as you are.  
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor.  Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything. 
If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and typically 20 to 30 people participate.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- LovingKindness

Hear the heroic tale of when a ferocious nor’easter split in half two tankers off the coast of Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and how the Coast Guard miraculously saved the day. The Disney Corporation has made a movie based on the book that will premiere two weeks after the lecture, and will star Chris Pine and Casey Affleck.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
San Shou or Sanda Kickboxing is a traditional Chinese Kickboxing style that is rooted in the application and training of Kung Fu. Punching, kicking, sweeps and takedown techniques are incorporated into the exercises of this martial arts style workout. Kickboxing classes can be a great alternative for people who have become bored with traditional workout routines, such as weightlifting or jogging on a treadmill. They also provide a way for people to enjoy a serious aerobic workout while learning real Kickboxing techniques.  
This fun and challenging class is a great opportunity for people of all skill levels to get involved in a new and exciting fitness class. No prior experience or equipment is needed for this class.

Class session run for 10 week at a time.  Sessions are $50 a person for one time a week or $75 a person for two times a week.
results.name: Kickboxing

group.name: West Roxbury Fitness & Martial Arts Meetup

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: In anticipation of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's imminent absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!

Description:

People say public speaking is one of the scariest things to do in life. That is only true if you never had the chance to practice in front of a crowd. In this class, you will learn to give three types of speeches: informative, persuasive, and inspirational. From developing your ideas on paper to performing in front of others, the process of giving speeches will become easier and more comfortable. And through giving regular impromptu speeches, you will practice organizing your thoughts and speaking off-the-cuff both clearly and calmly. In this way, you will gain the confidence needed to deliver excellent speeches for your next business presentation or social event. If you have a message, it's time for you to be heard.

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
We’ve been wounding ourselves (and each other) since the dawn of time, and herbs are all-stars in this department. Different kinds of wounds are handled differently, so we’ll base our class there: what to do for small cuts, large and possibly deep cuts, puncture wounds, burns, abrasions, and avulsions. We’ll cover appropriate ways to wash, debride, and cover each type of wound, as well as what sort of dressing is appropriate at each stage of the healing. At each step we’ll discuss the best herbs (and the best way to apply them) to speed healing and recovery for each type of wound.

Of course, if you have an emergency room handy, that may be your best option, but sometimes that won’t be available – so come learn how to handle these issues yourself, with confidence!

Wednesday, January 13th, 2016
7:00pm – 9:00pm

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

Sacred Creation: Common Street Lectionary Project Every Other Wednesday beginning 1/13/16, 7:00-9:00 p.m., Meditation Room

Join us as we partake in a communal exploration of sacred creative works that provide us with deeper meaning, guidance, and connection to the Divine in each of our lives. We aim to open ourselves to creative works beyond the Bible, to listen for the Divine voice in other places—and as a community take them seriously as mediating Wisdom. These sacred creations might be poetry, fiction, scriptures from various religions, spiritual works, artwork, specific biblical passages, songs. For example: Sufi poetry, writings of Thich Nhat Han, Van Gogh's Starry Night… whatever speaks to you. Our goal is that as a community we will formulate a Common Street Lectionary (a collection of creative works we find sacred) to use alongside the Bible in our weekly Sunday Circles and other settings. We hope to have a first draft of this lectionary to begin using by September 2016. Please join us in this on-going creative project! Start gathering those sacred creations you find most meaningful!

More info contact Ian: [masked] or Kate: [masked]

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!):

10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5

results.description:
This evening will feature two presentations, beer and pizza. Come spend an evening hanging out with the local Progress Community, including members of the OpenEdge development team.

1) Data Plus

In 1990, faced with the demise of the minicomputer market, Data Plus migrated its Hospitality-specific  back office system to Progress. For an IDE, Xponent, itself written in Progress, was chosen to provide forms-based Progress 4GL code generation, report generation, and source code control. Continued development of the Xponent system itself ended a number of years ago, and we realized that a complete system rewrite was required to modernize the application using Object Oriented programming with modern n-tier architecture. We were able to bring the current code up to OE 11 as a stop-gap measure to continue deployment on current client and server operating systems. After two-plus years we are about to launch the eighth generation of our product using GUI for .NET, an OO programming style and the Progress App Server. This presentation is intended to describe the evaluation and selection process that we went through with the assistance of Progress and others in the Progress community to create an entirely new system.

2)  Roundtable Software  Projects must be on time and under budget. With ever increasing demands, maintaining mature, consistent software configuration management practices is critical to ongoing success … but is not always an easy thing to accomplish. Built on and for the OpenEdge platform, Roundtable TSMS can provide the tools to make those practices clear, repeatable, and scalable, while also reducing time-to-market, improving product quality, and ensuring SOX compliance. This presentation explores how the Roundtable TSMS plug-in for Progress Developer Studio helps to provide these benefits and more for hundreds of OpenEdge development teams worldwide, large and small, putting them firmly in control of their development projects.  

We expect members of the progress OpenEdge development team to be present at this meetup well.


We will serve Pizza, Beer and Soft drinks. Looking forward to seeing you.

Tom
results.name: Presentations from Roundtable Software and Data Plus

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapters 13 & 14, of Part III & IV, in the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly readings and questions.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], with any questions.

READINGS:

PART III

CHAPTER 13: MONETARY CALCULATION AS A TOOL OF ACTION

PART IV

CHAPTER 14: THE SCOPE OF CATALLACTIC PROBLEMS


QUESTIONS:

1) What is monetary calculation, and what is required in the means of production?

2) Where does the term capitalism originate from, and how is it linked to monetary calculation?

3) Which type of action would be lacking in a socialist society? 4) Why did Mises believe the natural sciences was not enough to steer the use of scarce resources?

5) What is the field of study referred to as catallactics? 6) In what sense can we say that men are always seeking the maximization of profit?

7) Does a pure market economy exist, and does the answer affect how economics are conducted?

8) Why must economics study the situation of an isolated economic actor?

9) What is the final state of rest, and how does the market price differ from the final price?

10) What is the driving force of the whole market system, and why is it unnecessary to hold cash in a world without change and certainty?

11) What distinguishes the stationary economy from the evenly rotating economy, and what is the role of the entrepreneur in a stationary economy? 

12) Is the socialist system compatible with the concept of a stationary economy? Is it relevant?


SEE YOU AT THIS WEEK'S AUSTRIAN ECONOMICS MEETING!
results.how_to_find_us: Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.
results.name: MONETARY CALCULATION AND THE SCOPE OF CATALLACTIC PROBLEMS

You

The Person Sitting Next To You


** All Ages / $5-10 Sliding Scale **


https://www.facebook.com/groups/sonicosmosis

“What is Sonic Osmosis?”

Ask me tomorrow and you may get a different answer. Today, Sonic Osmosis is a playground for Improvised Music. If you ever met Improvised Music, you know she has a free spirit. She doesn’t like being told what to play, when to play, or whom to play with. Sadly, many venues don’t have the patience to indulge Improvised Music and her whimsical ways. “Sell more drinks!” they scream at her. Thank [higher power] for Out of the Blue Too Gallery!

Once a month (or so), we book a handful of groups and solo performers who have made the foolhardy choice to court this lovely, impetuous muse. Each group/artist plays at least one 10-20 minute set, at some point during the night -- no set times, because of course, Improvised Music would scoff at the idea.

Mixed in between these sets, we shake it up! Hopefully you aced AP Statistics, because any permutation is possible in these untethered moments. Members of different groups might form an impromptu ensemble; two or more groups might fuse into a super-group in a brilliant stellar collision…

And maybe…bold audience members, who came with noise-makers in tow, step into the playground and add their verse to our collective ode. Don’t worry -- no one will pressure you to participate, for the muse surely would not approve.

Hopefully, by the end of the night we have expanded our vocabulary, sensitivity, and imagination, had some fun and satisfied our insatiable muse!

If you’ve still got questions about what this is all about, my name is Marc, leave me a message! I may or may not have answers, for I cannot claim to fully understand this ethereal temptress…
results.name: Sonic Osmosis #5: Free Improv Hootenanny

results.description:
After a short holiday hiatus, join us in January for "The Rise & Fall of Great Powers" by Tom Rachman!

As a child, Tooly Zylberberg led a peripatetic existence. Paul, her less-than-attentive father, took her from from her unfit mother, and he and Tooly traveled from Australia to Bangkok, thanks to his short-term, government-funded computer assignments. Left to her own devices much of the time, it seemed inevitable that Tooly would fall in with a ragtag group of ex-pats—mercurial Sarah, Russian literature lover Humphrey, and their Svengali-like leader, Venn—who took her under their collective wing. What is not predictable, however, is that Tooly will be abducted once again when Venn and company elevate her from mascot to compatriot. Rachman, celebrated for The Imperfectionists (2010), spans the last 30 years in this tale of a rocky road to adulthood. Over the course of flashbacks and fast-forward escapades, Tooly gradually pieces together the jigsaw of her unconventional life to confront a complete picture that isn’t always comforting. Rachman’s kaleidoscopic second novel demonstrates that one’s family is very often made up of the people you find and who find you along the way.

We'll be calling ahead for a table, so please keep your RSVP up to date.
results.name: LITERATURE AND LIBATIONS - The Rise & Fall of Great Powers by Tom Rachman

How important is it to cultivate past friendships? How important is it to develop new friendships?

If you get a chance, here's the article: http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/10/how-friendships-change-over-time-in-adulthood/411466/

results.description:
This is the regularly scheduled Wednesday Night MeetUp for the Martial Arts


Together In Motion has opened their gym for our group for Tuesday Nights typically to 9:30 PM


7:30 to 8:00 is centered around those with limited background and the focus is on a basic physical Self Defense system incorporated with progressive boundary setting.

8:00 on the pace picks up with a very open format gathering of Martial Artists of diverse backgrounds who work until everyone gives in to the night.

Donations are always welcome and go towards Not Me! a non profit organization dedicated to providing instruction, conditioning and training to at risk populations

Visit Not-Me.Org if you would like information on the group the donations benefit.

This open mat time is open to all levels and backgrounds of martial arts, typically this is a self directed group which allows everyone to work on practice of their choosing.

Past meetups have had flow drills, throwing practice, locking practice, punching mitt and kicking targets. This really is an open format which allows members to question what they have been taught, share with others and just practice with no pressure of joining a school or formal system.

If you've been out of practice for years or months but want to start doing something again this is the place!

Please join us with a friendly spirit, bring whatever equipment you have or just yourself, uniform or running shorts makes no difference to us. The Together in Motion facility has a large open area with raised spring hard wood floor with dense mats covering, so it is adaptable for just about any type of practice.

Mat shoes or Socks are preferred on the practice surface

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

The Power of the Inbox: E-mail Marketing Tips & Tricks


What is the first impression you give when they see you in their email inbox? And when they see you there, what do they do?

Attend this powerful seminar and walk step-by-step through the keys to effective email marketing:

• Explore what email marketing really is (and isn’t).

From exploring why regular email doesn’t work through uncovering insider tips and tricks (like automated list building tools!) attending this seminar will give you the keys to the most effective marketing you can do: email marketing. 

Limited seating available.


To register for this event, please click on the event page below:

Light refreshments included!

This event is an Online Webinar - You Must Register Here to Gain Access. 

Summary:

While existing crime drivers continue to plague organizations across the globe, names like CoreBot, Shifu, and Sphinx are all are new banking Trojans that emerged in 2015, marking relentless progress and escalation in the cybercrime arena that stretched over the entire year.

Alongside emerging new threats, perhaps the most marked trend in 2015 was the adaptation of both older and new malicious codes to uncharted territories, in search for more and easier money.

Join our live crimeware-focused session for a retrospective view of 2015 cybercrime and the threat trends we can expect in 2016.

Your Speaker: 

Limor Kessem
Senior Cybersecurity Evangelist
IBM Security

DO NOT WAIT UNTIL THE LAST MINUTE TO REGISTER - SECURE YOUR SPOT IN ADVANCE 

This event is an Online Webinar - You Must Register Here to Gain Access. 

Additional Resources about CyberSecurity:


Richard Stiennon is undoubtedly one of the top global authorities as it relates to cybersecurity. 

His latest best selling book: "There Will Be Cyberwar"  is a fascinating must read! 

Richard is a mentor at CyberLaunchVC and partner at TrueBit Cyber Partners.


You can follow Richard on Twitter here. Send him a Tweet, he loves to engage.

----

The recent startup boom has created some of the world’s fastest growing new companies, and the strategies and methodologies they used can also be leveraged by employees and enterprises of all sizes to create innovation. 

If you would like to learn how, then join us on our free "How Employees Can Innovate Like Entrepreneurs" webinar.

This webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute), and feature special guest David Kidder, best-selling author of "The Startup Playbook", and Co-Founder and CEO of numerous successful companies - such as Clickable (acquired by Syncapse), SmartRay Network (acquired by LifeMinders), and Net-X (acquired by Target Vision). Through David’s most recent company, Bionic, he has helped some of the world’s largest companies become more entrepreneurial, like GE, Boeing, and Tyco. 

On this webinar you will learn: 

- How employees can adopt the same entrepreneurial strategies and tools used by the world’s most successful entrepreneurs 

- How employees can instill a “builder-mentality” in their organizations from the ground up 

- How company leaders can build an entrepreneurial culture in organizations of any size, to facilitate quick learning, risk taking, and exponential growth. 


We hope you will join us!

Meditation practice develops concentration, which allows us to calm and steady the mind and give us clear access to our natural wisdom. This practice is 30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion.

results.description:
http://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/241939/hubfs/BEE/BROOKINGS_logo.jpg?t=1452287965539&width=469

Beyond bitcoin: The future of blockchain and disruptive financial technologies 

HOSTED BY:

The Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy

To Register for this remarkable event you must click HERE.

When: Thursday, January 14, 2016, 1:15  – 3:00 PM EST 

What: 

Bitcoin, the digital currency, has attracted both attention and controversy. But the most potent innovation is not the currency itself. Rather, it’s the technology that undergirds bitcoin, the distributed-ledger technology known as the blockchain that allows payments to flow through an economy in an entirely decentralized way—without banks or other intermediaries. This infant technology could change the financial system; think the Internet before browsers. It could reduce the cost and increase in the speed and accuracy of financial transactions; it could truly disrupt the banking business. Or it could fizzle. But already it is raising a host of policy questions – about financial stability, consumer protection, choking off terrorists' finances, and tensions between established and upstart financial institutions and between regulatory agencies.

On January 14, the Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy at Brookings will explore the future of distributed ledger technology, paying special attention to the innovation’s impact on financial services and policymaking. Hutchins Center director David Wessel will convene leading industry and policy experts for a panel discussion. After the session, panelists will take audience questions.

You can join the conversation and tweet questions for the panelists at #BeyondBitcoin.

To Register for this remarkable event you must click HERE. 

Personal Note: 

We are very fortunate to have the opportunity to participate in this event with such an elite institution and distinguished panel. Big thank you to Camilo M. Ramírez of Brookings. 

EVENT SPEAKERS:

David Wessel

Director, The Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy

Senior Fellow, Economic Studies

@davidmwessel

http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/experts/w/wesseld/wesseld/wesseld_1x1.jpg?w=70

Michael Barr

Nonresident Senior Fellow

Economic Studies
