University of Michigan Law School

@michael_s_barr 

http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/experts/b/barrm/barrm/barrm_1x1.jpg?w=70

Brad Peterson

Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer (CIO)

NASDAQ

http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/events/2016/01/14%20bitcoin/participant%20bios/peterson%20brad/peterson%20brad_1x1.jpg?w=70

Digital Currency Group

http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/events/2016/01/14%20bitcoin/participant%20bios/silbert%20barry/silbert%20barry_1x1.jpg?w=70

Conference of State Bank Supervisors

How to Grow Your Instagram Account Using Analytics

WHEN: January 14, 2016 @ 2:00 pm - 3:00 pm EST AMERICA/NEW YORK

ORGANIZER: Sprout Social -Michael Patterson @SproutSocial

HOST: The Art of Social - Peg Fitzpatrick

CO-HOST: Sprout Social - Michael Patterson

SPONSOR: Sprout Social

TOPICS: MARKETING STRATEGY- SOCIAL MARKETING - SOCIAL MEDIA 

A practical webinar with social media superstar Peg Fitzpatrick to help you create an engaging Instagram presence that grows. Jam-packed with actionable tips, this webinar will help you get a handle on creating an Instagram strategy and provides valuable insight into using Instagram analytics.

Why attend this webinar:

1. You'll learn how to grow your Instagram presence.

2. You'll learn how to manage multiple Instagram accounts.

3. You'll get Peg's personal easy-to-use Instagram work-flows.

More information about the speakers:

The Art of Social - Peg Fitzpatrick - Author - Twitter @PegFitzpatrick

Peg is a social media strategist and popular blogger writing on her own website and across the web. Peg has spearheaded successful social media campaigns for Motorola, Audi, Google, and Virgin as well as having been brand ambassador for Kimpton Hotels. The Art of Social Media: Power Tips for Power Users is her first book.

Sprout Social - Michael Patterson - Digital Marketing Specialist - Twitter @MPatterson22

Michael heads up the co-marketing initiative at Sprout Social, and he spends most of his time creating content across a number of channels. When he isn't researching new ways to drive online traffic, he can usually be found exploring Chicago's unique neighborhoods and breweries.

Information about the Organizer:

Sprout Social is a social media management platform for businesses that realize social media presents a unique opportunity to engage with current customers while discovering new opportunities.

Mobile ready Recording available,  Slides/PDF available

Added Instructions - How To Register: 

Webinara helps you find webinars for different areas of interest, and notify you when there is a new webinar, within your own areas of interest. 

All webinars provided by Webinara are hosted by companies from around the world using different webinar platforms to provide you the webinar. 

When you click Register for the webinar, you need to be logged in to Webinara to come to registration page. 

If the webinar has 1-click registration, and you are logged in to Webinara, you can click the 1-click registration and you will automatically be registered for the webinar. Check your email for the webinar confirmation email, and click the webinar URL to access the webinar.

If the webinar registration button says Register, you need to be logged into Webinara, and when clicking the Registration button, you will be redirected to the webinar registration page for webinar organizer. Register there to get webinar confirmation email. Check your email for the webinar confirmation email, and click the webinar URL to access the webinar

You can login to Webinara or register to Webinara using your email, or just click Sign in with Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn.

Release Date: 1/22/2016

Rated: R

Synopsis:

Jason Kelly [Zac Efron] is one week away from marrying his boss’s uber-controlling daughter, putting him on the fast track for a partnership at the law firm. However, when the straight-laced Jason is tricked into driving his foul-mouthed grandfather, Dick [Robert De Niro], to Daytona for spring break, his pending nuptials are suddenly in jeopardy. Between riotous frat parties, bar fights, and an epic night of karaoke, Dick is on a quest to live his life to the fullest and bring Jason along for the ride. Ultimately, on the wildest journey of their lives, “dirty” Grandpa and his uptight grandson discover they can learn from one another and form the bond they never had. This outlandish comedy also stars Julianne Hough, Aubrey Plaza, Dermot Mulroney and Adam Pally.

In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, four times in the year.

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers. 

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion.

results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other. 


Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.


This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little significance unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more significance.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 5 years and is happy to share ideas.

The meeting location is Panera Bread in Quincy, which has wifi and is visible from the North Quincy T stop on the Red Line. The location could possibly change, so please check back with the event page just to confirm the location before heading off to the meeting.

-------------------------------------------


* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.
results.how_to_find_us: Quincy Center Branch of Thomas Crane Library. Go to top floor - meeting room is on parking-lot side of the building. MeetUp sign will be on door.
results.name: Options Monthly Meeting for Boston Traders Meetup

results.description:
This meetup event is on the general subject of populating a search index.  We've got 5 presenters that will talk about the subject: two being a "how we do it" at XYZ company, and the others being more general in nature with some mentions of specific open-source tools.  Essentially everyone using a search platform devises their own approach, usually using some tools to get the job done.  Sometimes fairly simple, sometimes fairly complex.  There's a lot to learn from each other!

Presenters:

• David Smiley -- a review of some ETL tools, and demo Apache NiFi

• Gus Heck -- proposal/ideas for a document processing pipeline


• Bob Lindenberg (TIAA-CREF) -- "how we do it" at TIAA-CREF using Solr


• Simon Rosenthal (DRG) -- "how we do it" at DRG, using SolrCloud


• Igor Motov --  Logstash and Beats with ElasticSearch

I/we look forward to seeing you, and learning what you might have to share too.

Keep in mind the location of this meetup is at Basis Tech (near Alewife, Cambridge), not Black-Duck.


Some food will be available, sponsored by Basis Tech & LucidWorks.

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

The French Cultural Center is hosting a free ($5.00 donation suggested) French film, "Poulet aux Prunes" (2011).

Even though this is a free event, a reservation is required.


You may register online at 

http://www.frenchculturalcenter.org/index.cfm/events/scheduled-events/cine-club-de-lalliance-poulet-aux-prunes/

or via phone at[masked]-0400.


When you register online there is a confusing message stating that members will be asked to show Member Card at the door.  This message does not apply to free events.  Just to reconfirm, this is a public and free event, however registration is required. 

This is a relatively small venue which seats approximately 70 people.  Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

The film starts at 6:30 pm, however the meeting time for this event is set for 6:00 pm in the reading room.  The film will be presented in the adjacent room, the ballroom.  The plan is to gather and meet-up in the reading room and then go to the film viewing room at 6:30 pm.

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

** *

Event Description

91 minutes | French with English subtitles | Drama, Comedy

Directors: Vincent Paronnaud and Marjane Satrapi
Actors: Mathieu Almaric and Edouard Baer

About the Film

After his beloved violin is broken, Nasser Ali Khan (played by Mathieu Amalric), one of the most renowned musicians of his day, has lost all taste for life. Finding no instrument worthy of replacing it, he decides to confine himself to bed until he dies. As he awaits the arrival of death, he is carried away by visions of the past, particularly of his lost love. The film lets the spectator accompany him on this bizarre and strangely beautiful journey. This stylish fairy tale is directed byPersepolis's Vincent Paronnaud and Marjane Satrapi.

To view the trailer, http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1663321/


Directions and Parking Information


• Getting here via public transportation (MBTA)Green Line

Get off at Arlington station. Walk north along Arlington Street toward the Charles River. Turn left onto the third street, Marlborough Street. The Center is at the end of the block, at the opposite corner on the right.

Via the Orange Line or Commuter Rail

Get off either train at Back Bay Station. Walk north along Clarendon Street toward the Charles River. Turn right onto the fifth street, Marlborough Street. The Center is at the end of the block, on the left corner.

• Parking

Parking is available at the Boston Common Parking Garage (located at Zero Charles St, below the Boston Common Park) on Saturdays all day and on week days after 4pm for $10. Buy your discounted ticket with our receptionist.

http://www.frenchculturalcenter.org/index.cfm/about-us/directions-hours/
results.how_to_find_us: in the reading room at 6pm
results.name: French Film Screening - "Poulet aux Prunes" (2011)  - Free

results.description:
Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there! 

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We will start gathering outside the Cleveland Circle Starbucks at around 6:15pm... see you then!
results.name: Thursday's Reservoir Romp

results.description:
Storytelling is one of the biggest buzzwords in business. Do you know how to effectively use stories in your pitch, presentations or meetings to create value for your audience? Join us to practice the art of storytelling and learn how you can use stories to make you and your business stand out. Takeaways:

• Learn tips and tricks on how to find and tell stories to be more successful in your business and personal life. • Discover ways to make your story more engaging and memorable.

• Improve your communication and leadership skills by using the power of storytelling

Be ready for hands-on activities!

Instructor Kit Pang:

Kit Pang is a public speaking consultant and trainer. He loves to work with entrepreneurs to hone their storytelling skills while offering engaging and insightful experiences through communication seminars for organizations.

Currently, he is the President of the Federal Toastmaster Club of Boston and a member of the Advanced Access Toastmaster Club in Brookline. Kit is also a TEDx Speaker Coach and the founder of BostonSpeaks, a Meetup group dedicated to connecting speakers in Boston. Kit has won numerous awards in public speaking and actively participates in story slams and poetry slams throughout Boston.

Thank You To Our Sponsor: Northeastern Crossing!
results.name: Business Communication Mastery: Storytelling

results.description:
This month's Boston Clojure Group Meetup will be held at Akamai, in our building at 90 Broadway in Cambridge, MA. on the 12th Floor. 90 Broadway is near the corner of Ames St. and Broadway, next to Meadhall. See map


Please have picture ID for building security. Late arrivals after 7pm may have to wait until someone is available to escort them to the meeting room.


Meet & Greet starts at 6:00. Group activities will begin at 6:30.


Agenda for this meeting: 2 Talks - Quil and Devcards


Talk #1) Super-fun with first-class shapes in Quil - Elena Machkasova

Description: This talk is a short recap of Elena's Clojure/conj talk. Quil is a popular Clojure graphical library, but as is it has a very imperative feel to it. Two recent additions to Quil help programming in a purely functional style:

functional mode ("fun-mode") middleware by Nikita Beloglazov which is a functional MVC model for handling state: one needs to supply event handlers that take the old state and return the new one.

A small library for creating and manipulating first class shapes that was developed by my students Thomas Hagen and Ryan McArthur last summer. It allows defining shapes, such as rectangles, ellipses, imported images, etc. as values in a program, combine them into complex shapes using functions such as “above” and “beside”, and then draw them on a specified position on the canvas when needed. The approach is modeled after the Racket programming language.

The combination of the two approaches provides a “super-fun” mode that is beginner-friendly, purely functional, and abstracts over a lot of low-level details.
Bio: Elena has been teaching computer science at University of Minnesota, Morris, an undergraduate public liberal arts college, since 2003. Her Ph.D. is from Boston University. For the last couple of years she has been working with students on a project ClojureEd that focuses on putting together a CS1 course (a first course that students would take in a CS major or a minor) that incorporates Clojure.


Talk #2) Focused UI Component Development with Devcards - David Mohs


Description: Devcards is a ClojureScript development tool by the author of Figwheel, Bruce Huaman. It creates a UI with "cards" pulled from your codebase, which allow you to focus on a single UI element during development. The documentation is great, so this demo will focus purely on motivation and practical usage.

Bio: David is a software engineer at the Broad Institute, a YC Founder, and formerly an engineer at Google.

results.name: 2 Talks: Quil and DevCards

results.description:
Note:  To reserve your spot, go to www.llbean.com/adventure .  See the note at the end!

Even in this high tech GPS era, nothing can replace the value of a compass and paper map. L.L.Bean’s founder, Leon Leonwood Bean, once said, "If you get lost, just go straight back to camp." If only it were that easy. 

In this course you'll learn how to read a compass, orientate a map to cardinal directions, take bearings on an object, and convert those bearings into a map course that you can follow using the compass.

This is possibly our most popular course, and a required skill if you're really going to start exploring the outdoors.

Note:  This meetup will always say "full" with only one person attending (the organizer).  This is to ensure we don't have competing registration lists (one Meetup, one LLBean).  Just sign up at www.llbean.com/adventure, find the store of your choice and sign up!  See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Ask any rep in the store where to find the clinic!
results.name: Clinic:  Basic Map & Compass Navigation

results.description:
Hi All, this will be the 2016 kick-off "Open Analytics" meetup. I'm scheduling these to occur at least once a month. 

Please submit your presentation or idea for a presentation, talk, demo that fits under the broad heading of "Open Analytics"

The envisioned format will be:

6:30-7:00 - Sign-in, Networking, pizza & beer

7:00 - 7:10 - Message from our sponsors

7:10 - 8:45 - 2-3 talks of about 25-45 minutes long with Q&A

8:45-9:00 - Thanks and ideas for next month's meetup

To use the Teradata space everyone will need to sign a form from the Security department.

January 2016 Speaker Agenda:

Anindita Mahapatra 

Building Realtime Analytics Pipeline with Spark and Kafka and using familiar sql-based queries to uncover insights from devices, applications and infrastructure data leveraging Jupyter web interface.

Tom Morris - Pending

"Data cleanup, transformation, and exploratory analysis - a hands-on introduction" with a peak at the new OpenRefine 2.6 features. OpenRefine (formerly Google Refine) is a powerful tool for working with messy data: cleaning it; transforming it from one format into another; and extending it with web services and external data.

Douglas Moore - Backup

"Big Data 101 for Data Scientists" - Highlight Hadoop capabilities as related to the role of a data scientist. The talk will expand the awareness of the tools and when to select Hadoop and Big Data vs. more traditional approaches.
results.how_to_find_us: Take elevator to 5th Floor
results.name: Open Analytics Boston - short talks & demos

results.description:
Components and Dependency Inversion: or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Encapsulation by Jeffrey Horn

You want to use components, but they're not yet routable. I'll demo a simple application that almost entirely componentized. This architecture with a simple app makes the "data down, actions up" principle a bit overkill. I'll demo how to bind the store to your component using dependency injection, keeping the component actions and markup clean and simple.


ember-engines by Dan Gebhardt

Dan will talk about engines in Ember and the soon to be released ember-engines addon. 

Just started using a cool library or technique at your job? Tell the group about it with a 5 min lightning talk.

Please get in touch with the organizers if you have a topic you'd like to present!
results.name: Components and Dependency Inversion plus ember-engines

results.description:
Is It a Sharpie or a Golden Eagle?
A Workshop on Accipiter and Eagle Identification

Most people can easily see the difference between a sharpie and a Golden Eagle, but many people have difficulty telling a sharpshin from a Cooper’s, and a Cooper’s from a goshawk or redtail! Adult Bald Eagles are rather easy but separating immature Bald from Golden Eagles is more challenging now than ever! This 1.5 hour workshop is designed to help you learn to identify accipiters and eagles. Everyone will be expected to discuss some of what they see and think with others in the workshop. Bringing a field guide or ID app and even binos is optional. Requirements include a paper notebook or tablet and a pen or pencil, and a sense of humor. Paul M. Roberts has been observing hawks for over 40 years. Some days he thinks he can identify most of what he sees, but he learns the most from his mistakes.

The meeting will be in the Community Room on the Lower Level of the Library.
results.name: A Workshop on Accipter and Eagle Identification

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay

Essence of Healing is excited to once more  present Sifu Donald Wong for a free introductory Qigong class on Thursday, January 14th at 7:00pm


Sifu Donald Wong will talk about Qigong, let you feel and see Qi, lead you in several exercise that will reenergize your body and enhance your physical wellbeing. 


Time permitting Sifu Donald will be willing to work on the physical discomforts of as many attendees as possible.


Sifu Donald Wong has been studying and teaching, Qigong and martial arts since 1965. He teaches  weekly classes in Bostons, Chinatown . Sifu gave a class  at Harvard University, Mind, Body, Medicine, and Health this past October.

Sifu Donald studied 10 years under a monk Grand Master Lam Sang and 3 years under a Doaist lady, Sifu Li.

Sifu Donald has done seminars in Asia, Europe, North America, and the Islands,  as well as doing a seminar at the Tai Chi Gala for the last 5 years.


This is a free event but please RSVP as space is limited! Doors open at 6:45.

Questions call[masked] or [masked]

results.description:
This is a program for those interested in accessing and maintaining higher consciousness. Much of the evening is in silence as you receive 3 crown chakra activations to lift and expand your energy field, bringing you to a felt sense of union with divine Source energy. Expect to feel profound peace, openness, expansion, and love.  As all Lightbearers are invited and needed to extend and help hold higher vibrations for others on the planet, part of this class will include using meditation, intention and imagery to spread the vibrations we receive.


Sacred l music plays for the entire evening.  Expect to maintain higher consciousness, giving you a sense of non-dual awareness....being with what is...total acceptance of everything within you and outside of you.

We are all in our awakening process...becoming awake to the Presence within us and living, speaking, loving and creating from that place. To access and maintain that truth of who we really are requires us to let go of any limiting beliefs, habits, memories. Then we can more fully embrace and embody the higher consciousness of our true Self.

Judy guides this class based on her ongoing deep studies and experiences with conscious awakening.  The sweet, profound results of expansion in consciousness occurs in moments. At these meetings we can freely express and connect with like-hearted souls as we share in these powerful energy transmissions. All are welcome to join us and share your own experience of conscious awakening...your challenges, inspirations, intentions and joys. If being in sacred energy appeals to you, you will love this gathering..


"So much peace, it's amazing."
results.name: Spiritual Awakening; with crown chakra activations

results.description:
We're back! After a brief hiatus during the Grove Kickstarter (check us out!), the Urban Agriculture Meet-Up returns. This time, let's talk about the importance of gardens in schools and their positive impact on children and communities. Gardens have been used in schools for well over a century, bringing a sense of environmental stewardship to children by creating positive experiences with nature, food, and our mentors. Today school gardens have taken a turn into the 21st century. With modern advancements in agricultural technology these "Learning Gardens" have opened the door for students to learn well past plant anatomy and cultivation techniques. S.T.E.M Curriculum is nurturing a nation of great thinkers that may improve our current outlook on the environment, our food and our culture.

Looking forward to seeing some familiar faces and new attendees! There will be snacks, beer and good conversations so please join us and lets slow roast some food for thought.
results.name: Lets Talk About School Gardens!

results.description:
Thursday night figure drawing has an emphasis on one long pose, giving time for more involved approaches.  Painters and drawers welcome to this informal and supportive group, meeting in Damon's painting studio.


A few warm up quick poses will be followed by a long (2.5 hour) pose, with breaks for the model.

Members pay $10 as on Monday night, non-member drop-in is $25.  Membership fee for each month of $25 brings discounts on drawing and painting sessions and classes.  Pay membership fee online (see left-hand column) via paypal or credit card, or in person with cash or check.  First session of the month would therefore be $35 ($25 membership fee plus $10 session fee) and each session thereafter would be $10. 

Thanks!
results.how_to_find_us: corner of Central Street and Vernon Street, big brick building.  Park on Vernon street in front of building or in lot behind building.
results.name: Long Pose Drawing and Painting Session

Don't you like to help your community? 

Wouldn't you like to easily meet young professionals in Boston?

Join us for our popular Bikes not Bombs volunteer night. 

We'll be partnering with the Boston Volunteers for this exceptionally popular celebration. 

This is my favorite hands-on volunteer event. No experience necessary.

A couple more popular young professional communities will be joining us including: 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers 

Don't you like Adventure: Brookline Community

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

We hope you can join us!

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

P.S. What is Bikes not Bombs: Bikes not Bombs

P.P.S. Learn more about Boston's most popular Meetup: the Boston Volunteers

results.description:
Welcome!

Winter Feast for the Soul (more details below) is a 40 day commitment to stillness. The Looking Glass Counseling will be committing to this, meeting on Thursday evenings, 7-8pm beginning January 14th (opening) to offer an opportunity to sit/meditate in a group. Additionally, we will explore a variety of ways to meditate. We will meet every Thursday, concluding on February 25th, to close and share experiences. Free, donations will be accepted.

The Winter Feast for the Soul event takes place every January 15-February 23, and unites people in their commitment to a 40-day practice of stillness. The commitment to 40 minutes of practice each day of the Feast allows people to have a life changing experience of the importance and impact of stillness. We embrace all forms of practice that bring an individual to a period of stillness in their daily life. Whether it is winter or summer where you are in January, we hope you will join the more than 20,000 people worldwide who participate each year.
results.name: Winter Feast for the Soul-group meditation/sitting

results.description:
This group meets every Thursday at 7:00 pm. for an hour and 15 minutes of meditation and mutual support. If your looking for someone to do something to you, or for you, keep looking ! If your willing to show up and work on yourself ,with kindness and patience, that's what we're doing together here. We are like geese flying together ,each one "drafting" off the others , and supporting the others at the same time. The average attendance for this group is probably 4 or 5 people, even though most don't RSVP on meetup, so don't be afraid that you will be the only one there if you don't see other RSVPs.(Is that a word?)

  Thank you for your kind attention, Randy
results.name: Join us for a guided meditation followed by discussion ,reflection and questions

group.name: Meditation group at Breathewellness, Cook Lane,  Marlborough

results.description: Come check out dragon boating with Living Root! We're a co-ed dragon boat team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. This is a great way to get in shape, stay in shape, meet people, and do something fun and competitive. How to get there: We practice at the pool at the JFK Elementary School in Somerville. Walk through the outdoor basketball courts to the rear of the building to find the pool entrance. Take the stairs down to the ground floor and head through the locker rooms to get to the pool. Practice will begin poolside at 7 pm. Wear athletic clothing. Although we won't do any swimming, you will get somewhat wet. Parking is free in the school parking lot. The T station at Porter Square is a 5 minute walk away. Practice will last an hour and 45 minutes. We provide paddles and all the necessary equipment--just bring yourself! No paddling experience is required. We have an excellent coaching staff who will teach you everything you will need to know. We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice, and you're welcome to join us. Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked] [url=http://www.livingroot.org/]www.livingroot.org[/url]

results.name: Indoor Paddling Session

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.
results.name: Join us as we discuss A Course In Miracles and apply its principles to our lives

group.name: A Course In Miracles Discussion Group - Carlisle

results.description:
Yang style Tai Chi is a Chinese Martial Art learned through flowing movement and practiced with focused breathing and a calm mind to develop health, internal awareness, and martial power.  A type of moving meditation, the slow, smooth movements gently stimulate the internal organs and joints, and improve energy circulation.

Tai Chi has many benefits including:

Increase energy, Balance, Flexibility, Internal awareness and power, and ease symptoms of many health problems

Tai Chi is a gentle, low-impact exercise suitable for adults of any age and varying physical ability.  From beginners to advanced practitioners, this program is a great fit for everyone interested in learning this ancient art.

Class session run for 10 week at a time.  Sessions are $50 a person for one time a week or $75 a person for two times a week.

results.description:
• Do you feel overwhelmed, anxious, worried or stressed-out too much of the time?

• Do you feel unable to feel joy most of your day?


Come to experience states of deep relaxation and inner calm, and to learn how meditation can serve you in bringing more ease and joy into your life.  And, I  always make it easy for you!


This evening is a complimentary "check it out" opportunity for the 4 week series starting Jan. 21st.  

We will have 3 guided meditations along with tips and discussion to help you release your cause of stress, and to build and reinforce positive thinking patterns that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy (even when you're not meditating!).

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class to deepen your learning, and to help you carry the positive feelings, insights and lessons experienced into your day and life.

“Ann's guided meditation class is like a mini-relaxation get-away. It was not only relaxing, but also heart-warming and very inspiring. I walked away feeling much more at peace and content than an hour earlier; and with a few good new tricks up my sleeve for meditation practice. I would recommend this class to anyone that wants to just plain enjoy life more.” Nancy

“I just want to comment on your meditation: Awesome! I was really stressed out today, worried mostly about job and home hunting. This helped me to calm down and feel at peace within the first few minutes. Thanks! ” Melissa

“I am leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, and full of love. I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned in your class will help me very much. Thank you!!!” Julia

“Ann was wonderful! I came into the room after the rush of the day and was immediately at peace. Her calm, focused and patient nature was so welcoming. I am still using the techniques taught in the class.” Linda

“In the world we live today, the peace, relaxation, and happiness that come with Ann's techniques are not to be missed.”
results.how_to_find_us: Main St. is at the light across from Walgreens and Trader Joe's plaza on Route 9

results.description:
THis time of year you will probably encounter the challenges posed by photographing in high contrast situations, and may even take images in which the highlights have become too bright or the shadows too dark.  A classic example is when your photos of snow come out looking grey.

Mastering the various metering modes on your camera is a way to get more control over contrasting situations and is an important skill for creating images in which the key elements are correctly or creatively exposed.

If you want to learn how to master this essential feature of your camera then come along to this meetup.  We will be a fairly small group, just 8 attendees,  so you will be sure to get plenty of attention.

Led by professional photographer, Ian Murray, you will spend three fun and informative hours learning when to rely on Matrix/Evaluative metering and when to switch to spot metering. You will learn the advantages and disadvantages of partial and center weighted metering and get plenty of opportunity to try all these essential features for yourself.

The meetup will run from[masked]pm will cost $35. The meetup is suitable for all levels.You will need a camera that will allow you to select spot metering in addition to the standard evaluative (Canon) , or matrix (Nikon)  metering modes. Most  digital SLRs have this capability as well as some compact pocket cameras.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter through the EMTS entrance at 201-205 Oak Street and head to the second floor.  Call 339-499-8506 if you get lost
results.name: Mastering Your Metering Modes

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
ImprovBoston's Sketchhaus! We've got a wild and weird night for all y'all tonight. Buckle up: it's gonna be a killer night of comedy.

First off, we have the bizarro comedy stylings of The Rekcus. When two new lovers are naked for the first time, there is an electricity that creates a scent that is arousing to them, but will nauseate any passersby. What we're saying is that you're better off seeing The Rekcus perform than hearing about it second hand.

Then: your headliner: INTERESTING POINTS with panelists Steve Delfino (Terrible People), Laura Clark (Good Loser), Kevin Quigley (Naked Comedy Showcase), Jenny Chilikian (Mendoza Line), and Matt Kona (The Comedy Studio) and your host Josh Poirier! What is it about funny people that makes them interesting? Is it the things they know or the things they do? Is it the memories they share or the lies they make up? Whatever it is, it's hilarious. Boston's best comedy panel show is BACK. Five comedians answering questions, having fun, and making you laugh is the name of the game!

And: our first OPENHAUS of 2016! That's right - YOUR sketch comedy open mic. Bring an untried five minute (or fewer) script, we'll provide the actors, and see your creation ON STAGE! Free with your ticket to SKETCHHAUS!

Featuring your host Laura Clark (Terrible People, Good Loser), and Special Guest Stars Matt Kona and noted Los Angeles comedian Jenny Chalikian! A singular night of fantastic comedy. See you at 9!

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Arisia is a volunteer-run convention that covers all aspects of science fiction and fantasy literature and media. Arisia strives to create a big tent environment that builds community among the varied groups and interests within fandom. Panels, parties, masquerades, films, and games - there is something for everyone.

Attending Arisia does require registration, which you can do at http://www.arisia.org/. At Arisia 2016, the Boston Sci-Fi and Fantasy Meetup will have it's own table in the Fan/Community section from Friday through Sunday. If you are looking to find other people in the Meetup, all you have to do is stop by our table. It will serve as a central meeting place for us as well as give us a chance to advertise our organization to the whole Arisia community. 

Since we have a fan table, we need to sit at the table to tell others what our Meetup is about. You can sign up to man the table here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1dOrneuDhuGrWGJpuC_NSmkg_c0wk-ugRUYh4qLLwp_g/edit?usp=sharing

The preliminary Arisia schedule is now posted (http://www.arisia.org/Schedule), so please plan accordingly. Additional fan table details are given on the sign up page.

Feel free to plan other specific meetups for Arisia, this is a general event listing for us to start planning and to sign up for the fan table. I will also set up a group chat for us as Arisia approaches.

Message me if you have any questions!

Fun Competition + Delicious Craft Brews = A Great Night

results.description:
The last several months we've been on a quest to find a new venue for Meet and Greet One More Time.  We've been concentrating on the Newton Center area since it's on the T for our public transit folks and centrally located with lots of available parking for those of us driving.  We've been looking for the right balance of ambiance and good food/drinks, reasonably priced.

I think we found it!  The Deluxe Station Diner.  It's located in the old train station building that's right at the Newton Center T stop.  It has a very comfortable feel to it; warm and friendly.  We sit at the bar if we have a small group.  We grab a table  for a larger group.

They have a number of interesting specialty drinks.  I have tried the Blueberry Lemonade and the Apple Pie.  Believe it or not, those are both vodka drinks.  They were both very good and reasonably priced.  The kind of drinks that you need to be careful with because it's easy to forget there's alcohol in them.

I'd classify the food as "comfort food".  We've had the burgers, mac & cheese, curried chicken, meatloaf, chicken pot pie, and fish & chips.  Everything has tasted great and was reasonably priced.

Several large municipal parking lots are nearby. Meters are free after 6:00 pm.

MBTA: Green Line, “D” train, Newton Center stop. When you come up the stairs from the train tracks, you are on Union Street. The diner is inside the old brownstone Union Station.

Bus #52 from Watertown Square (www.mbta.com for schedule and exact route).

Driving:

From the Mass Pike (east-bound):
Take exit 17 and make your first right after the set of lights, onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From the Mass Pike (west-bound):
Take exit 17 and go straight off the ramp. After the ramp, you will go through two sets of lights. After the second set, turn left at the sign that says "Newton Centre/Boston." You will be making a 180-degree turn and should stay in the right lane. Take your first right after the 180-degree turn onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From Route 9:
Take the Newton Center/Centre Street Exit. Follow Centre Street until you reach Beacon Street. Take a right onto Beacon Street and park in the parking lot on your left or on Beacon Street.

Inviting you to a new Monthly Hochoka

A Healing Song & Poetry Circle for Community

On Friday eve, January 15th, you are invited to attend a new program for offering song to represent and share healing wishes for self and community. 

This new offering of healing song/poem circle for community is inspired by a Lakota healing tradition for community members. It involves providing an opportunity for a group of people to gather and experience community-minded healing by listening and offering words of uplift through song and poetry within a circle setting.

The public is invited to attend as part of circle and also welcome to bring a song/instrument, poem or spoken offering of well-wishing, healing and uplift for

 oneself, other individuals in need and community.

Our first Hochoka circle will be offered on Friday 6:30-8:30pm January 15th.
This date was selected as it is close to Martin Luther King Jr. holiday so we can also keep in mind the powerful, hopeful and healing words and songs inspired by his work.

This event will be offered and facilitated by Carolyn Waters, Amy Mevorach and Cheryl Perreault

The monthly Hochoka gathering will take place at the Common Street Spiritual Center located at 13 Common Street, Natick MA.

For more information contact: Cheryl Perreault at [masked]

results.description:
This sound healing is a celebration of Makar Sankranti, a festival which symbolizes harvest and the end of the winter solace which makes the day last longer than night. It is time to let in the light people!

In Sanskrit, the movement of the Sun from one zodiac sign into another is called Sankranti and makara is the movement of the sun into the zodiacal sign of capricorn.

In this sound healing, we will focus our intention on manifesting strength, as capricorn is a power sign. We will also focus on what we are harvesting in our life now and what we want to plant for our next harvest!

--------------------------------------------------------------------

So if you come to the Buddhist Temple for a sound healing, what can you expect? 

When you come in, you take your shoes off, then you walk to the Dharma Hall which will be on your immediate right at the top of the stairs. We'll start with a short introduction and discuss each of our intentions for how we want to work with the sound and then meditate for a few minutes to tune into each of our specific intentions. Then, everyone will sit or lie down on super comfy pillow mats (bring your own blanket) and we'll begin our journey into sound.

I start by playing the 500 pound cast-iron temple bell and then I move into the sweet sounds of my Tibetan singing bowls. What follows, I can't exactly say, as the sound decides what it wants to say. But you can expect to hear the rainbow voice, the sound of the overtone chant singing with the tibetan bowls. You won't be able to tell which is which but this is all part of the dance. You will even feel what it's like to have the bowls played on you as the sound moves your energy where it needs to go. Tingshas, tuning forks, rattles and more are all part of the play as the sound moves you to rest at your destination without ever having moved. So, please, come and feel something unique. You never leave anywhere exactly the same, but when it comes to sound healing, you will leave sounding more like yourself :)

Pllease bring a blanket to enhance the comfort of your experience! Offerings are freely accepted :)


Much love,


Brian Russo

(781)[masked]

[masked]

<a href="https://www.facebook.com/BeSoundNow"></a>

Pairs of dancers form a circle, with dance moves called out by one person, a caller (or "líder" or "cantante" in Spanish). Many moves have hand signs to complement the calls; these are useful in noisy venues, where spoken calls might not be easily heard. Most moves involve the swapping of partners, where the partners move around the circle to the next partner. The combination of elaborate dance combinations and constant movement of partners creates a visually spectacular effect.

$50 for 8 classes
Drop-ins welcome: $15

results.description:
Witaj Polish Meetup!

Pierwsze, chciałem wszystkim dziękować za naszą pierwszą spotkanie w Cafe Polonia. Cieszę się że wrzyscy przyjechali! Drugie, na następne spotkanie chciałbym zorganizować meetup na kręgle! Jest fajna lokacja w Fenway i jest więcej miejsca dla ludzi którzy nie mogli przyjechać do restauracji. Będziemy zaczynać spotkanie o 7 godzinie. Jak nie możesz przyjechać na 7 a chcesz jeszcze się spotykać, do zapraszamy jak masz chwile czasu! Otwieram RSVP na 20 osób dziś i powiem wam później jakie są oceny na kręgle i pożyczanie buty.

Do zobaczenia w Jillian's & Lucky Strike za tydzień!

Eric


Hello Polish Meetup!

First, I want to thank everyone for our first gathering at Cafe Polonia. I'm glad everyone made it and had a fun time! Secondly, for our next gathering I would like to organize a night of bowling! There's a great location in Fenway and a bigger space to host more people (especially for those who weren't able to make it to the restaurant). We'll start the meetup at 7 pm. If you can't get there in time because of work or another commitment, we still invite you to hang out for a little bit!

I'm opening the RSVP for 20 people today and will let you all know regarding prices for bowling with shoe rental.

See you all at Jillian's
& Lucky Strike in a week! Eric
results.name: Polskie Spotkanie i Kręgle! Polish Meetup And Bowling!

results.description:
• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

• We gather together every other Friday evening. Check the schedule, grab your drum (or use ours) and have a blast!

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta
results.name: Boston Drum Circle Friday at DrumConnection!

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description:
I can't resist Our Man In Havana and Alec Guiness doing anything - just as I can't resist Greene.  It will probably be too late to go someplace and talk after, although I am open to it.

Here's the description:

Our Man in Havana by Carol Reed (UK, 1959, 111 min.). Alec Guiness plays James Wormold, a British expat enjoying a modest life as a vaccuum cleaner salesman in Cuba. When a fellow Brit attempts to recruit him into the British Secret Intelligence Service, Wormold agrees because he can’t turn down the generous paycheck – but he hasn’t the first clue how to uncover political secrets to send back to London. So, he simply invents them. When his made-up intelligence reports begin to have real-life consequences for Wormold and his friends, he must try his hand at espionage (and a whisky-soaked game of checkers) to save them from harm.

Adapted from his “entertainment” novel of the same name, Our Man in Havana draws on Greene’s own experience as a secret agent in MI6.  This vocation brought him to war-torn and developing areas throughout Europe and Africa, where he was exposed to a world of political intrigue that would deeply influence his work.

Presented in DCP.

results.name: All right I can't resist Graham Greene:  Our Man In Havana

results.description:
Dance with us from 7:45 pm - 11:30  at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.

The fabulous, fun-filled event begins with a class from 7:45 to 9:15  5 Rhythms / Funky Jazz 

The 5 Rhythms will offer us  a personal moving map to be fully embodied with our physical and emotional selves and create an easy flow warm up. From there we will deepen our focus alignment  into  funky jazz dance warm up and across the floor routine and finally a funky dance combination to bring us more deeply into fun. 

Stay and Dance to dj'd Music until  11:30pm music provided by some extraordinary DJs. This week DJ Mystical Michael.

DJ Mystical Michael has been a DJ for more than thirty years, beginning with turntables, then moving to CDs and now digital on his MacBook. He plays a global and eclectic mix of rhythms and tempos to provide opportunities for creative and fun movement including American Pop, R&B, Rock, Dance, Deep House, Deep Chillout and orchestral music.

Michael has been a Reiki Teaching Master and Counselor for more than twenty years. He is Director of Providence Zen Center in addition to a Life Coaching and Reiki Counseling private practice.

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

</a>

<a href="http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts">

results.description:
RESCHEDULED FROM LAST WEEKEND

Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Monroe and Washington. We will use the steep Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail to get to Monroe and then Crawford Path to get to Washington. We will use Gulfside Trail and Jewell Trail to return to the trailhead. The AMC's Lake of the Clouds hut and the Mount Washington Observatory are closed for the season.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 9.5 miles and climb about 4,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours to complete. This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/1-Mt-Washington-6288

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/4-Mt-Monroe-5384

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.30365675019486&lat=44.27038780496076#.VjjteITO5_Y 


=== What to Bring ===


Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Ammonoosuc winter lot which is just below the Cog Railway Station on the right/south side of the access road. It is past the signed WMNF parking lot. According to Google Maps this spot is about 162 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 48 minutes to drive there.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/KWdbtWu3X7z 

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.name: NH4K ... Monroe and Washington (ADVANCED)

results.description:
Join us for our weekly weekend run! We'll be meeting in Back Bay and logging some miles around Boston. All paces and runner levels are welcome! 

During the winter months, we'll be meeting at the Boston Marathon RunBase on Boylston street for our Saturday runs. They have lockers and showers available for your use though you'll need to provide your own lock if you plan to use a locker. 

Please post your desired pace and distance when you RSVP. 

Route: The forecast is calling for steady rain and high winds on Saturday morning, so the consensus is to keep this one on the shorter side.  We'll also be without our chief navigator, so we'll stick to an "oldie but goodie" 5 mile route along the river (with an option to tack on some extra miles for those feeling adventurous...or if the weather holds). 

As a reminder, we are now meeting at 8:30 AM to avoid any mixups with the RunBase group that convenes at 8:00. 

5 Mile Route

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

President opens meeting and welcomes guests

Toastmaster's Welcome

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches

Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction

Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations

Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org

<a href="http://watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org/"></a>

results.name: Watertown Saturday Toastmasters Club Meeting

results.description:
Hike/snowshoe the trails of East Randolph while gaping at fantastic views of the Northern Presidentials. This should be an easy to moderate hike unless we have to break trail with snowshoes. This hike will mainly appeal to people Redlining the White Mountain Guide but others are welcome. We'll hike the following trails and more if time permits. 

Bee Line - 1.5 miles
The Diagonal - 1.3 miles
EZ Way - 1.0 miles
Burnbrae Path - 0.5 miles
The Glenside - 0.2 miles
Groveway - 0.2 miles
Bluffway - 0.1 miles
Wood Path - 0.9 miles
Grassy Lane - 0.1 miles
Short Circuit Path - 0.1 miles
East Pasture Path - 0.7 miles

There's bound to be some extra hiking as we go back and forth on trails when loops are not possible. If interested, please put yourself on the established waiting list.  A yes list will be provided as soon as possible. 


Criteria: All hikers must have cold weather gear, head lamp, snow shoes and foot traction . 


All attendees must read, understand and agree to the waiver/liability as outlined by this website. 


=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===
As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons. 


=== What to Bring === 


Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models: 


Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.
• MSR Lightning, Revo, or Evo. 
• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 
• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12. 


You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if  you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons. 


The days colder so put the hydration bladder away and switch to insulated water bottles. Bring enough food to keep your energy level high - you will burn more calories hiking in the winter. The days are shorter so be sure to have a headlamp with a spare set of batteries (preferably lithium since they work better in the cold). Use this link for a list of items needed for most winter day hikes: 


http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf 


Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 
Guests aren't permitted.
Dogs aren't permitted.

This class will introduce attendees to the fundamental concepts of what CAD (Computer Aided Drafting/Design) is and how it is useful. We'll discuss the history of various CAD tools, and then focus on one particular piece of software, DesignSpark. Attendees will learn to download, manipulate and modify files from existing libraries, as well as how to construct their own parts from scratch.

Prerequisites:
Windows laptop (can be provided by Lowell Makes with advance notice)
Basic computer literacy
Prior experience with CAD software is helpful, but not required

The software for this class is a version of the 3D CAD system, SpaceClaim, that is available for free under the name DesignSpark Mechanical. Instructions to download and install the software are available here: http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/tutorial/designspark-mechanical-download-installation-and-activation

If you can come to the class with the software installed, you will be able to move into the training material more quickly. We can help get you set up before the class begins as well.

results.description:
A day to create one single stunning image! 

What is it about? 

We will meet at the studio for an introductory session in which I will explain a proven approach to creating a strong image, we will then travel to a local destination where you will put the approach into practice by creating a single photograph. 

Returning to the studio in the afternoon we will analyze our single image and look at post-processing it using a combination of Lightroom and Photoshop. 

What will you get out of this workshop

The aim is for you to walk away with a strong image to add to your portfolio. 

However, the process of achieving that aim is likely to prove more informative and valuable than the finished product.

During the day you will be forced to slow down and put into practice a series of steps that will definitely improve your way of seeing and composing the potential shot.

Who will benefit from this?

Anyone who has a reasonable grasp of their camera control, and who is looking for a better approach to creating strong photographs. 

The class will run from 10am to 4pm
results.name: The Expert Session: One day- one image!

Reduces levels of stress

What you will learn?

Is it a paid event?


Yes it is. We ask for a small fee to be able to cover for the work necessary for the preparation and promotion of the event and pay for the operating costs (webinar etc.)

As you are a member of this group you automatically benefit from the Members only price. We suggest you also follow our blog and join the facebook group to further network with other participants.

Also, we will be there after the events to help you further answers questions or precise things you have heard during the event.

Feel free to ask us any questions prior to the event (and after).

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Jan 9, 16, 23, 30, Feb 6 and 13) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

Admission to the event is free, but please bring a donation of canned goods or toiletries to support Somerville Homeless Coalition’s (SHC) Project SOUP, the local food pantry that provides weekly community dinners and delivers groceries to individuals, families, elderly, disabled and homebound people in our neighborhood.
