Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Nectar is a talk-free dance inspired by conscious and ecstatic dance. It is a space to enjoy and explore embodiment, physical expression, and the body’s wisdom. After an unguided warm-up period, the Facilitator-DJ leads a brief opening circle on a theme or guided practice, followed by a playlist of music—beginning spacious and mellow, gaining intensity, and arriving back into stillness. Participants are welcome to move, dance, and be still as their bodies desire. Nectar closes with a sharing circle in which participants are welcome to speak about their experiences in the dance.

Nectar is offered primarily for adults. Children are welcome with adult accompaniment provided they can follow the talk-free and intentional structure and be mindful of their impact on others in the space. Kids under 6 can come for free, and ages 6-12 for half price ($5-7). $10-15 for adults.

Nectar was created by Amorn O’Connor and Harrison Blum, and is supported by a rotating crew of Facilitator-DJs.

Please note that many more people attend than RSVP via Meetup!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be two flights up from the ground level in Studio 2.

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers, 

Let's enjoy the Boston Bel Canto Opera Winter Concert (Artistic Director Bradley Pennington) at the Dante Alighieri Cultural Center.  

Beautiful arias will be sung by the exquisitely talented Bel Canto vocalists. Included in this performance will be Italian arias from La Traviata, I Pagliacci, Un Ballo in Maschera,Madama Butterfly and Cavallieria Rusticana.


http://pirandello.com/bel-canto-opera/


Meet and Greet Details


Concert starts at 2:30 pm, lets meet at 2 pm at the entrance.  The plan is to meet at 2 pm, congregate as a group, meet and greet and greet one another, and then go into the seating area at 2:15 pm.  

Admission Price and Ticketing


General Admission is $21; for seniors and students is  $18. 

For Pirandello members, the concert is free for members who are in good standing. If you are a member you may bring a non-member guest or guests for $10 per person. 


There is no advance purchasing for these tickets, you may purchase them at the door. 

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 


Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds.

I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.


Joana

*******************

Parking and Public Transportation Information

Parking is available at the Dante for “early birds.” Overflow parking is available nearby at the Kendall Theater Cambridge at a reduced rate with validation from the Dante Alighieri Center. 

Near Red Line, Subway, Kendall Square T stop and bus stops (CT2, 85)

results.description:
Martin Luther King Jr. said: 
"Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere."

This January meeting's topic:

Nonviolent Actions...

and Martin Luther King Jr., the movie Selma, the link below, other nonviolent activists and actions, our nonviolent actions, our barriers to participating in them, and does talking about this together motivate us to participate in them more?


Please watch the movie before this meeting if you haven't seen it yet. But if you don't see it, no worries, there will be lots to discuss anyway.

Here is an online article that could be read (in addition to or instead of watching Selma) about the The Almost Forgotten Selma March.


Series description:


Even those of us living in the suburbs care about, and have a role to play in, the anti-racism movement. From frustration, fear, and anger to empathy, passion, and solidarity, this work can bring up a lot for everyone. Our supportive group discussions can help us get some clarity, perspective, and encouragement through the process. We will focus on a different topic each meeting, sometimes including films and discussions about printed materials …encouraging member feedback to help guide future topics.

The mission of this monthly group discussion series is to promote awareness of inequality, to build community, and to develop skills that address dismantling racism and oppression within a diverse, compassionate, and culturally sensitive environment.

All are welcome: People of Color, white people…people new to this topic and those involved and active for many years. Come with questions and/or experience to share with others wanting to learn more.

Hosted by Deb and Carlin, members of Boston Knapsack Anti-Racism Group.

If interested, please join Knapsack and RSVP to this meeting date (with no further obligations). Please change your RSVP if your plans change and you can no longer come so we can plan accordingly.

Feel free to post questions here too.
We look forward to hearing from you!

Parking is available on the street, and behind and beside the church. Come in the door at the parking lot side of the church, lower level.

Public transportation unfortunately does not go to Medfield.  But most likely someone going to the meeting would be available to give rides to/from the Framingham commuter train station, Riverside T station, or elsewhere. Leave a comment about your needs and we will try to get you to the meeting if you want to join us! Car-pooling rules!

Future 2016 dates: plan for 3rd Sunday of each month, same time. We will post here if that changes.
results.name: Anti-Racism in the ‘Burbs (Medfield, MA)

results.description:
Happy New Year!  New years is the perfect time for change and improvements.  This includes the drunk bookclub.  Instead of the 1 book/month selection, I thought maybe we will try genres and themes.

For our first bookclub of 2016, I selected "Steampunk".  If you found a book that you love, please leave comment or bring it to the bookclub to surprise us.

Etiquette & Espionage by Gail Carriger
Boarding school for spies, best friends, frenemies and corsets.  I highly recommend borrowing the audiobook.

Lady of Devices (Magnificent Devices #1) by Shelley Adina
Girl grew up in privilege, lost her fortune but gains her freedom to be a lady scientist/engineer.  First book free on Amazon and this is a shortish read.

This Monstrous Thing by Mackenzi Lee
A steampunk retelling of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.

Leviathan (Leviathan #1) by Scott Westerfeld
WWI history meets steampunk

Etiquette & Espionage by Gail Carriger

It's one thing to learn to curtsy properly. It's quite another to learn to curtsy and throw a knife at the same time. Welcome to Finishing School.

Fourteen-year-old Sophronia is a great trial to her poor mother. Sophronia is more interested in dismantling clocks and climbing trees than proper manners--and the family can only hope that company never sees her atrocious curtsy. Mrs. Temminnick is desperate for her daughter to become a proper lady. So she enrolls Sophronia in Mademoiselle Geraldine's Finishing Academy for Young Ladies of Quality.

But Sophronia soon realizes the school is not quite what her mother might have hoped. At Mademoiselle Geraldine's, young ladies learn to finish...everything. Certainly, they learn the fine arts of dance, dress, and etiquette, but they also learn to deal out death, diversion, and espionage--in the politest possible ways, of course. Sophronia and her friends are in for a rousing first year's education.

Lady of Devices (Magnificent Devices #1) by Shelley Adina

London, 1889. Victoria is Queen. Charles Darwin’s son is Prime Minister. And steam is the power that runs the world. At 17, Claire Trevelyan, daughter of Viscount St. Ives, was expected to do nothing more than pour an elegant cup of tea, sew a fine seam, and catch a rich husband. Unfortunately, Claire’s talents lie not in the ballroom, but in the chemistry lab, where things have a regrettable habit of blowing up. When her father gambles the estate on the combustion engine and loses, Claire finds herself down and out on the mean streets of London. But being a young woman of resources and intellect, she turns fortune on its head. It’s not long before a new leader rises in the underworld, known only as the Lady of Devices . . . When she meets Andrew Malvern, a member of the Royal Society of Engineers, she realizes her talents may encompass more than the invention of explosive devices. They may help her realize her dreams and his . . . if they can both stay alive long enough to see that sometimes the closest friendships can trigger the greatest betrayals . . .

This Monstrous Thing by Mackenzi Lee


http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/6/3/c/event_444301596.jpegIn 1818 Geneva, men built with clockwork parts live hidden away from society, cared for only by illegal mechanics called Shadow Boys. Two years ago, Shadow Boy Alasdair Finch’s life shattered to bits.

His brother, Oliver—dead.

His sweetheart, Mary—gone.

His chance to break free of Geneva—lost.

Heart-broken and desperate, Alasdair does the unthinkable: He brings Oliver back from the dead.

But putting back together a broken life is more difficult than mending bones and adding clockwork pieces. Oliver returns more monster than man, and Alasdair’s horror further damages the already troubled relationship.

Then comes the publication of Frankenstein and the city intensifies its search for Shadow Boys, aiming to discover the real life doctor and his monster. Alasdair finds refuge with his idol, the brilliant Dr. Geisler, who may offer him a way to escape the dangerous present and his guilt-ridden past, but at a horrible price only Oliver can pay…

Leviathan (Leviathan #1) by Scott Westerfeld

Prince Aleksander, would-be heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, is on the run. His own people have turned on him. His title is worthless. All he has is a battletorn war machine and a loyal crew of men.

Deryn Sharp is a commoner, disguised as a boy in the British Air Service. She's a brilliant airman. But her secret is in constant danger of being discovered.

With World War I brewing, Alek and Deryn's paths cross in the most unexpected way…taking them on a fantastical, around-the-world adventure that will change both their lives forever.

results.description:
BEGINNER TANGO: Absolute Beginning

Beginner Tango course is meant for people who either never ever danced Argentine Tango, took few classes long time ago or took few lessons quite recently but are not sure what they know or if they are ready for next level.

You will learn basics necessary to progress further. The material is presented in very organized manner allowing smooth progress from class to class. 

Please note that even if you dance other dances like salsa, swing, zouk or any of Ballroom or American Style dances, even if for years you took ballet, jazz, hip hop or any other of solo dances, you need to take the Beginner level class. The axis, the basis for the dance, musicality and partnership is completely different. Taking those 4 classes might be the life changing experience for you. It is obvious that having dance background helps, but it shall also give you enough experience to know that the basic classes are THE MOST IMPORTANT ONES, as they create a base for all your learning experience. What you don’t know will always and always chase you.

 It’s good to take this course to put all your information in order. You gain the necessary vocabulary and learn all the basic movements to be able to easily follow the explanations in higher level courses. Please respect our commitment to excellence. And make it your own.

No partner necessary. Join at any time – though we do recommend starting at the beginning of the cycle (see: http://www.ultimatetango.com/boston-classes.html for dates). You can take this course as many times as you find necessary for you.

The full course consists of 8 90-minutes classes plus exam/graduation even (about 4 hrs).


SIGN UP NOW: https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/ws?studioid=208847&stype=-7&sTG=25&sView=week
results.how_to_find_us: Follow your intuition and detective instincts. Still cannot find it? Email us at: ultimatetango@gmail.com
results.name: Dive into Argentine Tango: BEGINNER TANGO: Absolute Beginning

results.description:
Join writer, filmmaker of "Simply Raw: Reversing Diabetes in 30 Days," Eating Behavior and Psychology researcher, Tree of Life Teacher (trained by Dr. Gabriel Cousens), and author of the new book, "Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey," Michael Bedar, for a special presentation featuring themes, tips, and practices from his newly released book, and more! FREE. Optional dinner afterwards $11 bostonveg.org/events

Sweet Healing:

• Inspire and teach yourself to achieve workable health goals and live in sustained vital wellness.

• Use this breathtaking new book to go on a psychological journey that instills a lasting affinity for health and well-being.

• Pick up this book as a great read or a wonderful gift that keeps on giving to friends and family this Winter!

• Bring your questions, as Michael, the author, will discuss goals, emotions, and methods of gaining wellness all portrayed in the novel he wrote on the shift from dis-ease to thriving.

Find Out Why Well-Known Leaders, and Readers Alike, are Glowing about Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey:

"The new book by Michael Bedar, Sweet Healing, touches the heart and opens the mind's eye." – Dr. Brian Clement, Director of Hippocrates Health Center

“Sweet Healing rocks! It’s a heck of an adventure for novel lovers; it’s a tale that will touch anyone who has been affected by the epidemic of diabetes and chronic disease...a gripping read of fiction that will leave you inspired, motivated, and hungry for a healthier lifestyle. Devour this book and share it with your friends now!”  – Cathy Silvers, actor from the TV sitcom, Happy Days, author of Happy Days, Healthy Living, producer of The Healthy Living Show

Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey,' offers a proven and essential alternative narrative to help you observe and identify what blocks you in life, and incorporate lifestyle practices you can use for whole-person health.” - From the Foreword by Gabriel Cousens, MD, MD(H) author of Rainbow Green Live-Food Cuisine, Conscious Eating, and There Is a Cure for Diabetes

“Sweet Healing is filled with Michael’s dedication, caring, and generous personality, infused with serving and raising awareness for the world around him as if it were his own family. In this book you’ll find a great story to help avail yourself to wisdom and knowledge about eating and living a healthier lifestyle. A story written like this comes from someone walking his talk. Sweet Healing is inspiring to those suffering with preventable and reversible illnesses, so they may create new habits and ways of living that reinforce a loving, healthy sense of self.” – Debbie Merrill, US Figure Skating Silver-Medalist, author of Raw Truth to the Fountain of Youth, host of the Debbie Merrill Show

“For people searching, this book is a parable about waking up and getting your spark back par excellence! I heartily and excitedly recommend Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey as a boon to those who want to find out what’s possible in the realm of their well-being. Read it on a plane, in bed, in a book club, or on your train commute–just READ it!” – Nomi Shannon, Author of What Do Raw Fooders Eat 1 & 2, The Raw Gourmet, and Raw Food Celebrations

Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey now. It is an indispensable parable. It will take you on a possible journey to better health and a life empowered by positive choices, informed by proven research and presented as an entertaining read." – Mike Adams, the Health Ranger, editor of NaturalNews.com

"Sweet Healing - A Whole Health Journey is a 'Way of the Peaceful Warrior' and 'Celestine Prophecy'-type adventure for today's epidemic times." - Annie Padden Jubb, author of Secrets of an Alkaline Body, owner of LifeFood Restaurant Chain LA

“If you know someone who’s faced with type 2 diabetes or a degenerative metabolic health crisis, I highly recommend this inspirational novel! In Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey, the characters demonstrate how each small step in the process of healing builds upon itself. This book inspires readers to take a proactive approach to their healing and offers innovative tips for health, happiness, and longevity.” – Marci Shimoff, #1 New York Times bestselling author

“Sweet Healing is a heart-touching and inspiring novel about holistic approaches to healing and preventing metabolic syndrome and diabetes. With vivid storytelling, Michael Bedar helps us understand the deeper meanings of wellness and healing; uplifting and potentially transformational!” – Dr. Will Tuttle, author of the best-selling book, The World Peace Diet 

“This book was amazing. Michael Bedar’s expertise in his field of holistic healing is surpassed only by the dedication and love he has for serving people. Sweet Healing is a kaleidoscopic journey into the little known (until now) subject of naturally recovering from type 2 diabetes. If you are diabetic or know someone who is, read this book, and awaken into wellness. It just may save your life.” – Frank Ferrante, subject of the award-winning documentary, May I Be Frank, and author of the book, May I Be Frank

“'Sweet Healing' lays out a framework that can guide us all back to using food and movement as the most powerful tools to maintain our health and vitality. I use this book as a trusted resource with all of my patients diagnosed with diabetes and other degenerative diseases.” – Harry McIlroy, MD, Integrative Physician

Sweet Healing takes you on an inspiring whole health journey that frees you to enjoy every day of your life. Get life-altering inspiration and everyday practices to transform and sustain your wellness using this breathtaking new book to go on a psychological, physical, and soulful journey that is proven to leave you with a lasting affinity for healthy living now!


BIO:
Researcher, teacher, writer Michael Bedar is an avid investigator of eating psychology, behavior, and natural health, and is the co-director of the East Bay Healing Collective in Berkeley, CA. He is a frequent leader and guide in transformative courses and consultations. He was Associate Producer of the documentary film,Simply Raw: Reversing Diabetes in 30 Days. He graduated from Dr. Gabriel Cousens' Plant-Sourced Nutrition Master's Program and taught at the Tree of Life Center US for 5+ years. 

For his master's thesis, Bedar surveyed 200 people who have received a diagnosis of type 2 d

iabetes about their attitudes, beliefs, and satisfaction with their health outcomes. The results of this research helped form the basis of Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey so that it is effective in supporting people in sustaining the path to their desired health and vibrance. 

A book signing will follow the presentation. 

Behar's new novel "Sweet Healing: A Whole Health Journey" sells for $14.95 by cash or check. (No credit cards.) 

4:15 PM - Social Dinner (optional) 

Stay and enjoy Grasshopper's unlimited vegan buffet for only $10.70 + tax + tip

Includes appetizers, soups, salad, and numerous entrees. 

ALL WELCOME - No RSVP needed. 

Just turnip!


Date and Time:

Sunday, January 17, 2016
3 PM - Speaker (FREE)
4:15 PM - Buffet Dinner 

Location (for seminar and dinner):Grasshopper (an all-vegan restaurant)
1 North Beacon St., Allston (Boston) MA 02134
<a>[masked]</a> 

This is in Union Square, Allston (part of Boston) the intersection of Cambridge St., Brighton Ave., and North Beacon St. Buses # 66, 57, and 64 stop there. 

Closest subway stop is Allston St. on the Green Line B trolley (Comm. Ave.) Or, you could take the T to Harvard Square or Coolidge Corner, where you can pick up the #66 bus that stops a block from Grasshopper. 

Parking:  Free street parking; allow time to find a spot. 

Evelyn Kimber
Boston Vegetarian Society
www.BostonVeg.org
Info:  <a>[masked]</a> 
BVS
Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Cappella Clausura's vocal ensemble and chamber orchestra surrounds you with the sounds of sacred chants from medieval times through the present day. Led by director Amelia LeClair, this acclaimed performance and recording group is dedicated to the work of women composers throughout history, and for this concert they'll sing works by the Medieval era's Hildegard von Bingen and Arvo Pärt, the Renaissance music of Italian nun Raffaella Aleotti, and contemporary works by German composer Erna Woll. Doors open at 3:30pm, concert is at 4:00pm, general admission, get there early because seating is open and patrons sit in the front rows.

Goldstar discount, use this link:


https://www.goldstar.com/events/newton-ma/resoundings-tickets<a href="http://tinyurl.com/hh3py33"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: This is an unhosted meetup, have fun!
results.name: Attend "Resoundings" Sacred Chant Concert

venue.address_1: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138
venue.name: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
The oldest, established, permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and environs.

Please join the Fresh Pond Community walkers + five other meetup groups for this delightful sunset walk. 

Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 3 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 1/17 3:30

results.description:
Join The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Community Walk in Cambridge 

For the 200th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.


Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 1/17 3:30

results.description:
The movie starts at 4:15.  If there is interest, we can grab dinner in East Arlington afterwards.

In 2001, editor Marty Baron of The Boston Globe assigns a team of journalists to investigate allegations against John Geoghan, an unfrocked priest accused of molesting more than 80 boys. Led by editor Walter "Robby" Robinson, reporters Michael Rezendes (Mark Ruffalo), Matt Carroll and Sacha Pfeiffer interview victims and try to unseal sensitive documents. The reporters make it their mission to provide proof of a cover-up of sexual abuse within the Roman Catholic Church.
results.name: Go see the movie Spotlight

venue.address_1: Porter Square Shopping Center, White Street, Cambridge, MA
venue.name: Panera Bread - Downstairs

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.how_to_find_us: On the dance floor
results.name: Carver Den - Step it Up

group.name: The Original Steppers of Boston Inc. 2006

results.description:
To be a vegetarian is good for your body and soul! However, to be a well-informed vegetarian is even better.  Let’s plan to read together great vegetarian books, watch movies/documentaries and, later, discuss them in a circle of vegetarian friends. Book selections will be recommended by a professional librarian or by you. Please provide me with your wish list of books that you want to read together as a group. We will plan to meet on a monthly basis.


For our January discussion, you can either read The China Study (2005), watch the documentary Forks Over Knives (2011), do both or simply show up to join in for a discussion over a cup of coffee, a tea, a salad or a vegan ice cream!

About the Book:

The China Study (2005) is a book by Professor T. Colin Campbell, a Jacob Gould Schurman Professor Emeritus of Nutritional Biochemistry at Cornell University, and his son Doctor Thomas M. Campbell II, a physician. It had sold over one million copies, making it one of America's best-selling books about nutrition.

 About the Documentary:

Forks Over Knives (2011) is an American documentary film that advocates a low-fat, whole-food, plant-based diet as a way to avoid or reverse several chronic diseases. The film recommends a vegan diet, but calls it "whole foods plant-based" to stress that processed food should be avoided as well as food of animal origin.
results.name: Discussion of The China Study and Forks Over Knives.

results.description:
In what seems like a bit of Déjà vu, the Steelers are headed to Denver with a chance to exercise the ghost of Tim Tebow. Several key injuries loom large, but the Steelers are no stranger to a bit of adversity. 

Last Saturday saw our biggest turnout for a Steelers game in several years with over 150 Steelers fans jammed into CitySide. We are expecting a similar-sized crowd this Sunday so GET THERE EARLY.

Please RSVP if you plan on coming out so we have a relative idea of the crowd size. Cityside will again work with us to give Steelers fans priority upstairs, but please be patient.


For those that weren't able to grab a 2015 Koozie last week, we'll have plenty on hand Sunday ($1 each). 

See yinz in a few days!

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.name: THE QUEST FOR WELL-BEING USING YOUR 8 POWERS : THE POWER OF COOPERATION

results.description:
Alright, friends . . . get ready for the best and most delicious Soup Swap ever! Clear out your freezers. Dust off your coolers. And break out the Dutch ovens. This is going to be seriously fun.


Please feel free to invite your friends! Just add them to your RSVP so we can get an official head count. 

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •


HERE'S THE SCOOP:


1. Pick 1 recipe. Whether it's a family favorite, Grandma's specialty, or one you've ripped out of a magazine  . . . this event is the perfect opportunity for your culinary ideas to shine. This is not a vegetarian event, so if you have an amazing Italian Wedding Soup recipe, make it! To the vegetarian members of the group, mark your calendars for February 21. I'm planning a Vegetarian Chili Exchange for that day. NOTE :: Once you know what soup you want to make, please post it in the comments section. This will help avoid duplication and inspire a better variety of soups.


2. Containers. Since I consider myself a seasoned swapper of soups, I find that the 4 cup twist top storage containers are PERFECT for traveling and storing in the fridge or freezer. Plus, 4 cups of soup makes for a lovely dinner for 2 (or an individual lunch and dinner). See image below. You can easily find these containers at the grocery store or places like Target. Remember to buy the 32 ounce size. NOTE :: You may want to lightly wash them before filling them with soup. Sometimes the new plastic smell is overwhelming.

3. How much to bring? Now that we're all on the same page with the soup containers, let's discuss how many containers to prepare. Each person is asked to bring a MINIMUM of 8 containers — 6 for swapping + 1 for donating + 1 for sampling. You are welcome to bring more than 7 containers, if you're feeling ambitious enough—go for it! Essentially, whatever amount you bring for swapping, that's the amount of soups you'll be bringing home. For example, if you bring 10 containers for swapping, you'll leave with 10 different soups! NOTE :: Even though 20-30 of us will be coming together for this event, you do NOT have to bring 20-30 containers of soups—that's cray cray (but awesome).


4. Sampling the soups. We're going to have chafing platters set out to display our soups for easy sampling. No crockpots needed. One less thing to carry . . . hooray (plus the tables won't be near an electrical outlet). So, of the 8+ containers you're bringing, set one aside for sampling. I'll give you a bowl and a label to fill out. There will be plenty of  spoons and chips for tasting the soups. NOTE :: You don't have to bring a copy of your recipe, but I do ask that each of you write down a list of all the ingredients. This will be super helpful for everyone involved. Thanks!


5. Swapping rules. Though there will be a great variety of soups for this event, you will most likely NOT be bringing every type of soup home. If you brought 6 containers for swapping, you will be choosing 6 different soups to take home. During the "tasting" part of the event, you will be making note of the soups you'd like to potentially swap (almost like you're shopping for soups). NOTE :: There's no guarantee you're going to get the exact soups you want. It's up to the other person to decide if they want to take YOUR soup home, too. I know, it sounds confusing. I'll explain everything at the event. But trust me . . . it's going to be fun and no one will go home empty-handed!

6. Empty-handed. That leads me to the charitable part of the event. With the abundance of incredible food we'll be sharing together, I felt compelled to have each of us donate a container of soup for those in need. So, I've connected with 2 local families to whom we'll be giving our soups (and a gift basket of goodies from Prime Meats & Provisions). The following Monday, I'll drive to their houses to deliver the food. This small gesture will make a huge impact on these families. Thank you for doing your part to make this donation possible.

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

Prime Meats & Provisions is the venue for our soup swap. They're easily accessible from Route 128 (Exit 20A) and they're adjacent to the North Beverly MBTA train station. Parking available out front, along side of building, and out back.


I love this quaint local butchery (and mini grocery store). They support a lot of local makers, too . . . if you know me, you know that I'm obsessed with supporting and sustaining local entrepreneurs. If you've yet to visit Prime Meats, I'm delighted to be introducing you. It will be love at first sight, I guarantee it. Heck, you may even want to get some of your ingredients from them!


Beverages will be provided. There's also a Starbucks in the building next door.


Other than that . . . let's make some awesome soups and fill up our freezers for the winter season.


Again, feel free to invite your friends! Even if they are not members of the cookbook club, they are more than welcome to participate in our Food Swap events. Have them follow the directions listed above, and add them to your RSVP (so we have a head count). The more the merrier, I say!


Feel free to comment with any ideas, questions, or some fun stories!

I hope you can join us.

Warmly,

Jessica
results.how_to_find_us: Right next to the North Beverly MBTA station!
results.name: Food Swap — Soups!

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

results.description:
Come join us for an evening of dancing, music and food:
We will have a family dance with an open band (YOU!) followed by a dinner potluck ... and then onto our usual, wonderful, contra dance! Sunday January 17th, at 1950 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge MA.

5:30-6:30 Family Dance and Open Band
6:30-7 Potluck Dinner
7:30-10:30 Contra time! Caller: Luke Donforth
Music: Light Reaction Quartet (Kathleen Fownes, Jim Fownes, Jamie Oshima, Ness Smith-Savedoff)

**During the family dance portion, we would love to welcome you to join the OPEN BAND led by Light Reaction. A tunelist will be posted below by the band of BIDA is excited to be launching a new series of Family Dances! These will be family oriented dance afternoons in conjunction with our regularly schedules dances. Bring your kids! Tell your neighbors and schools! Come without kids of your own, ready to be friendly :) (Did you know that BIDA stands for Boston Intergenerational Dance Advocates? Well, kids are the upcoming generation, and a vital part of our community...) Potluck: please bring something to share, a serving utensil, and label what you've made for allergy courtesy. Dessert Potluck during the break -- Bring something to share! **Please feel free to join us at 7:00 for a beginner's lesson if you're fresh to contra dancing! Admission is our standard sliding scale of $5-12 for adults (and counts for the regular dance following, should you choose to stay) and $3 each for children. Bring someone new to Contra to the intro session and you both get passes for free admission to a future dance! Share the love. Public Transportation (recommended): We are across the street from the Porter Square Red Line stop.

Parking: Free street parking (meters and residential are open to all on Sundays). Don't park in the Shaw's parking lot because they tow.

See you there!
results.name: BIDA 3rd Sunday Contra Dance and Family Dance

results.description:
Let's talk about the role that mainstream and alternative media play in our lives.

Where do you get your news?  How do you get it? TV/Newspapers (the old fashioned kind..paper), online, radio, social media?

More & more often, I turn to Facebook shares as many of my friends refer links to reports/media that I wouldn't otherwise know about. I listen to NPR and also WRKO..I watch CNN & also Fox....I want to know what the breadth & scope of coverage is, especially when it involves the upcoming election, mideast politics and geopolitical affairs. 

Bev
results.name: Let's talk about the Media.. What's your choice? Mainstream or other?

results.description:
</a>

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

<a href="http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com">http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com


(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>
results.name: Speeddating Ages 23-33 - SOLD OUT FOR MEN

results.name: Round Robin Doubles at Woburn RC

results.description:
{How can we communicate so that each person hears the other and opens their heart to the other?  Come and practice the most powerful tool you may ever have to stay in relationship through the inevitable problems.}


Our Topic This Evening Will ....

... give you, and let you practice, a specific technique that you can use to help the other person open up and share what they really think, and to help them hear more clearly what you have to say.

This session is for anyone in, or wanting to be in, deep, connected relationship.  It could be with a partner, a family member, a friend, or even a co-worker.

With children:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oG_UlQrFmAY

This is for anyone who understands that sometimes communications can break down into confusion, resentment, frustration, withdrawal, or anger and who wants to learn a powerful method to extricate their relationship when they fall into that no win situation.

We'll talk a little about its application to Couple's Talk.  Partners complain, "My partner just doesn't tell me what is going on!"  What if there were a way that you could help your partner get more in touch with his/her feelings and express them to you?

We'll practice reflective listening and, a bit of, empathetic listening.

With Partners:

https://youtu.be/FEvldkFkgsc?t=3m01s

And, what you can do when you really want your partner to hear you?

It is not necessary to have your partner present, or even to have a partner.  And of course, partners are welcome.

While Dennis and Carol use this technique as a couple, you can use this method with anyone in your life to whom you are committed to maintain your relationship.   It does not have to be reciprocated.

With co-workers:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SZ-IH-V7oJ4

A form of "Reflective Listening", the technique we'll be practicing is ultimately based on Rogerian Client-Centered Therapy.   For the reflector, it includes meticulous, ego-less listening, reflecting back exactly what you heard, allowing corrections until you have it, and then empathizing with the perspective you heard.  For the speaker, it  includes speaking even if not clear what to say, listening carefully to your partner's reflection, iterating what you said to be closer to what you really feel and think, and speaking to completion.  If you follow the steps carefully, you will understand your partner, and, perhaps more importantly, yourself, much better, you'll empathize deeply with each other, and you'll both be in a position, and a mind-set, to find the win-win solution.


To attend, you do not need to be in a committed long-term relationship, nor do you need to bring a partner.  

... But if you have someone with whom you'd love to communicate better with, bring them!!

With employee:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7E_skS6TBXI


To Prepare ....

1) Recall a time when you were unable to get your partner to open up. 
2) What causes you to open up?  What causes you to close down? 


Readings: Overview of several Reflective Listening techniques.

Our Leaders This Evening

https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xta1/v/t1.0-9/10383666_10203500288341653_1291123165655219755_n.jpg?oh=5a86df785f75848bf05f7d0f3a71b144&oe=56B50347

Carol Pratt is a banking attorney, a wife, and a mother.  Her personal growth journey has helped her to open her heart.  She continues to practice and to learn and to reach out in love.  

Dennis Pratt is the founder of the Personal Growth Network.  In a prior life he was a serial entrepreneur.  He now organizes communities around personal growth.

Dennis and Carol have been great friends for 39 years, lovers and roommates for 36 years, and married for 35 years.  (Their relationship has been politically recognized for 32 years. )

During all that time they have weathered so many of the trials and tribulations that destroy other friendships.  

The biggest weapon they have in their arsenal -- the technique that they have used whenever they have been in the most crisis -- their one guaranteed method of reconnecting -- is "Reflective Listening".

Links

Most Important:   
  * Other, Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 
  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon?  
  *  Where are Heartbeat Salons

results.description:
Note: you must sign up at www.llbean.com/mansfield to reserve your spot. Please see note at end of description

Please join L.L. Bean Mansfield for our fourth annual Martin Luther King Day winter hike in the Blue Hills Reservation. For this year we’ll do a loop hike along the eastern, lesser traveled section of the Skyline Trail from Shea Rink in Quincy to Chickatawbut Hill and back. This hike will be on Martin Luther King Day, Monday January 18th at 10AM. The Skyline Trail is a strenuous and rugged trail that transects the Blue Hills Reservation from east to west. The summits of the numerous hills offer incredible views of downtown Boston, the Harbor Islands and the surrounding communities. Please consider joining L.L. Bean Mansfield on this challenging excursion. The full hike should run over 3 hours and cover over 6 miles. I’ll check trail conditions the day before and let everyone know what special equipment they’ll need to bring (snowshoes, traction devices, trekking poles, etc). We will do a shorter hike if trail and weather conditions are less than optimal.
Please dress appropriately for the weather conditions. Dressing in layers works best.
Wear appropriate footwear for hiking. Please bring water, snacks and any personal medicines and gear you may need as well. These outings are free but you are responsible to have everything you need. A camera and/or binoculars are always a welcome addition.
Leashed, people friendly, well socialized outdoor dogs are welcome at this venue.
Please arrive 15 minutes before hand because we want to get started on time.
If you have any trouble finding our meetup location please feel free to call before the event kicks off. Andy’s cell phone is[masked]-4503.
Look for Andy’s Green Honda Pilot with the “L.L. Bean Mansfield Outing Program” banner hanging on the side!

Sign up at www.llbean.com/mansfield

Note: this outing will always say "full" with only one person going.(the organizer)this is so we don't have competing lists of attendees.(one meetup/one LL Bean) Please sign up at llbean.com/mansfield
results.name: Martin Luther King Day Winter Hike on the Spectacular Skyline Trail

results.description:
Come out and meet fellow yoga nature and art adventurers on MLK Day! If you like to be outdoors, explore mindfulness and movement and look at the natural world with a creative eye,  you're in the right place.

We'll get to introduce ourselves briefly, do a bit of stretching, take a walk along the Muddy River, learn a bit about the natural history of the Muddy River and depending on weather may get to do a quick sketch or two.

Experienced artists, yogis, naturalist welcome- come explore in community!First time yoga and art explorers welcome. Leader (certified yoga instructor, MFA in art, and experienced naturalist)will provide guidance for those who want it, and encourage all to explore what feels right. Encourage focus on the feel/experience/process than on the product (pose or sketch).

There's a great MLK day celebration at the Museum of Fine Arts, art making and art tours and free admission and we will end our adventure a short distance away.
results.name: Yoga Nature & Art Adventure ! MLK day celebration!

results.description:
Let's join the Greater Boston Divorced and Separated Support Group and The Culture Vultures for:

Established in 1950, deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum is the largest park of its kind in New England encompassing 35 acres, 20 miles northwest of Boston. In 2009, deCordova changed its name from deCordova Museum and Sculpture Park to deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum to emphasize its renewed focus on sculpture and to support the institution’s goal of becoming a premier Sculpture Park by 2020. Providing a constantly changing landscape of large-scale, outdoor, modern and contemporary sculpture and site-specific installations, the Sculpture Park hosts more than 60 works, the majority of which are on loan to the Museum. Inside, the Museum features a robust slate of rotating exhibitions and innovative interpretive programming.

Check out the fall exhibitions:
www.decordova.org

The museum is closed for the holiday. Entrance to the Sculpture Park is free today. Waitlist priority will be given to those with posted face photographs and those who have reliably shown up for past events.
results.name: MLK Day Walk at the DeCordova Sculpture Park and Museum

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Make Jan. 18 MLK Day A Day of Service for the Cambridge Community
This is the 6th Annual Cambridge Day of Service that Many Helping Hands 365 has organized to celebrate the Martin Luther King Day holiday.
The event is free and open to the public.

All ages are welcome to help with hands-on crafts projects that benefit Cambridge residents in need. Join us for an afternoon of hands-on service projects! Make fleece scarves and blankets for homeless children and adults. Make Valentines for elders and veterans. Sort food, winter clothing, books and toiletries for people in need and more!
Come spend an afternoon making a difference in the lives of others. Many people. Many needs. Many Helping Hands.

Many thanks to the many organizations,city departments, businesses and individuals who help make Cambridge MLK Day of Service possible.

Don’t come empty handed!

Bring a can of food, gently used winter clothing or a children’s book for someone in need. We are also collecting and sorting donations of food, children's books and winter clothing at the event.

All ages welcome! We need everyone’s helping hands

If you are interested in bringing a GROUP, please sign up as a GROUP above (no need to give us the names of everyone in your group) or email us as soon as you can at [masked]. Once we have your registration and numbers we can place you together. It would be very helpful to hear from you before January 15th. Thank you!

FAQs

Who does our service benefit?
Your helping hands help thousands of Cambridge (and Somerville) families in need. Last year we made more than 500 fleece scarves and blankets for homeless children, teens and adults; more than 2400 Valentines for isolated elders, veterans, troops overseas and homeless parents and 1500 activity kits for children waiting in hospital emergency rooms. We collected and distributed more than 500 grocery bags of food to 12 local food pantries, dozens of bags of winter clothes to shelters and dozens of bags of childrens' books to local literacy programs. We reached approximately 7000 vulnerable children, teens and adults in our community.

Can we bring kids?
Yes! We've designed the projects to encourage even the littlest hands to be able to participate. We have had children as young as 2 and seniors 90+ lend their generous hands in service.

What are my transport/parking options getting to the event?
The best way to come is by MBTA. We're in Central Square on the Red Line. The #1 Mass Ave bus stops across from City Hall. There are some public parking lots nearby as well. Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?
Please feel free to email us at [masked]. We'll be in touch soon!

Can I bring a group from my company, church, school, sports team, Girl Scout troop, etc?
Absolutely! Please contact us as soon as you can (ideally by January 15), so we can be sure to place you together. You can register by filling in the Group Registration above (we need the name and contact for the leader of your group and the expected number in the group, but we do not need names of all group members) If you have questions, just email us at [masked]
Can I make a monetary donation? Yes! Donations pay for the supplies we use on MLK Day of Service. Thank you! I have ideas for you! Can I help?
Sure! We'd love to hear from you. [masked]
WHEN
Monday, January 18, 2016 from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM (EST) - Add to Calendar
WHERE
Cambridge MA - Central Square - City Hall and Cambridge Senior Center - 795 Massachusetts Ave Cambridge, MA 02139 - View Map
results.name: Make a Difference this MLK Day!

results.description:
Bring any Android project you like, weather you are currently working on a side project as a hobby, have a new startup idea you want to work on, or just getting started on some tuts, and interested in learning more about Android in general! This is a good way to learn among your peers, network, meet some new people, get some help or feedback, and maybe even collaborate on a project together. So bring your energy, passion to learn, and most importantly bring your selves... 


If you already have previous programming experience in Java, yet new to Android you are going to want to download Android Studio. For those completely new to Java we are looking to start up a virtual study group in Java, so keep an eye out for that, coming soon. We are also looking for mentors in Java for when we meet in person. We also started a Slack Channel, it's called AndroidBoston which we encourage you to join.  

Call for speakers, we are opening up the floor for brief talks at the beginning of the event, if there is interest. Very impromptu, and casual no slides needed, yet going over code is encouraged. We will have a separate breakout session for this, and each be given 5-15 minutes to present. We are looking for no more than three speakers on the following:

-Learning Java 101, what are the core building blocks to Java that everyone should know, what are some the pains to learning Java, and how did you overcome them?

-Product Design for Android: Have you published an app in the Google play store, what was your recipe to making an app that everyone loves?  

-Android Developer Summit recap, what were your key takeaways, and how will this change Android in 2016?

If you're interested in mentoring for our upcoming Java virtual study, want an invite to our slack channel, or itching to do a talk. Here is your chance! You can send me a direct message if you are interested.  

Don't forget to follow us @AndroidBoston

Special thanks to our host and sponsor for our next HackNight, Intrepid Pursuits..

Intrepid is an end-to-end mobile design and development company with offices in Cambridge, MA and NYC. With expertise in insightful product strategy, well-crafted design and proficient development for iOS, Android, Back-End and Rails, we help companies, from startup to enterprise, boldly navigate their mobile future. intrepid.io | @intpd 


Location, and directions....

Intrepid Pursuits is out of the Twine Factory in the Kendall MIT area. 

The address is: 


222 3rd Street, Suite 4000, Cambridge, MA...

You want to enter the building at the "courtyard entrance" which is near SECOND Street.  If you're driving definitely come in from the Second Street side, since you can't drive around the building from Third (though you can walk).  Take the elevator to the fourth floor.

Please come and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in Panera Bread, located in the Fresh Pond mall, about a 10 minute walk from Alewife station. The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play.

This meetup is officially canceled unless at least five sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.


2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, if you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.



OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block away from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza.  We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot).  When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q. What About X-Wing?
A. If you noticed, this spot is filling up the time previously scheduled for X-Wing Miniatures 100pts - so... as you may have guessed, Randy and I will be setting up a couple of x-wing miniatures tables for those of us inclined towards that game but still want to make the event more inclusive to other game genres (it is not often the wife allows me to invite my friends to play games, so I better make the best use of the time).
